} } } Length:: 0:10 MinsI own four of these cameras and two DropCam HDs. The two are very different, but for my purposes, the D-Link cameras are actually more useful.Connectivity: Both offer 802.11N 2.4GHz connectivity, which is fine except when there are many networks nearby and frequency congestion becomes a problem; 5 GHz would be much better, but isn't offered. Neither camera streams effectively with a weak signal. The DCS-942L can capture to the SD card, which is good to have if the signal is iffy. The DCS-942L also has a wired ethernet port. For your sanity, use wired ethernet if at all possible. (With Dropcam you have no choice but to use wireless.)Optics: The DCS-942L is VGA quality only, not 720p. But the lens on the Dropcam is wider angle, so the level of detail on objects is the same--the Dropcam simply shows more of the room. For a camera pointed directly at a door or hallway, it won't really matter. The bigger improvement comes from 1080p cameras such as the DCS-2230 which I also own.Night vision: The DCS-942L has much better night vision than the DropCam. The DCS-942L has four LEDs that glow rather noticeably; DropCam HD has several (maybe ten) behind tinted plastic that is more stealthy but blocks a lot of the light. Consequently, DropCam HD's night vision in mediocre, while the DCS-942L has good night vision for indoors.Live viewing: I use a Mac and an Airport Express router which does not support UPNP for on-the-fly port mapping. Therefore the MyDlink service will not stream video above 320x240 because it is relayed through the MyDlink website first. I find MyDlink kind of useless and just use the camera's built-in Web server for control. Dropcam streams continuously to their cloud service and does not depend on any special configuration for your router. They use Flash video for playback.Playback: Dropcam shows the entire recorded video, either 7 days or 30 days, on a timeline view, which makes it really easy and fast to navigate. If you receive a motion alert via e-mail, you click the link in the e-mail to go straight to the video when the motion occurred. The DCS-942L will e-mail you up to a 10-second video file, between 200K-2MB depending on settings and degree of motion, and you have to then go to the mydlink.com web site, access the camera's Web server directly, or go to your NAS if you have one to get the full-length video. However, because my DCS-942L's are set to record on motion, they have clips on the SD cards from as long as three months ago. (The D-link cameras automatically throw away old video clips to make room as needed.)Motion detection: The D-Link camera offers very flexible video motion detection where you can draw a specific region in the picture to capture movement. There are firmware issues in the D-Link when using highly irregular regions shapes, so keep the motion regions simple and rectangular. Both D-Link and DropCam HD, but especially the DCS-942L, have some trouble in very low lighting conditions, such as late afternoon indoors, and false trigger on video motion. On the DCS-942L, I had to set the sensitivity to 30-35% to stop it, but then the camera wouldn't detect any motion at all! For best results, use a normally bright region of the picture for the motion detection. Dropcam's video motion has no sensitivity or region adjustment but works pretty well, false triggering once or twice per day in early morning and evening. Unlike DropCam HD, the DCS-942L offers passive infrared (PIR) motion detection using a separate, dedicated infrared detector on the front of the camera. On the Medium or Low settings, it triggers reliably with ZERO observed false positives in my experience. High sensitivity will false trigger in very cold weather. PIR does not work through windows. Neither camera has I/O ports for connecting external sensors.Long-term cost: Once you buy the D-Link camera, it's yours. You record to an SD card or to a NAS on your network as your DVR. There are third-party services that stream 24/7 from the D-Link cameras to provide offsite DVR also. To do any recording with DropCam, you have to pay monthly fees that, for the 30-day plan, exceed the cost of the camera in about a year. You also need to upgrade your cable service if you have more than one or two Dropcams. With DropCam, you pay for simplicity and convenience at the expense of configurability.Scalability: Local recording means no bandwidth usage on your home Internet connection unless you are watching a live feed from outside your network, whereas the Dropcams use bandwidth 24/7. You can record continuously to files on an SD card (each file up to 6 minutes) for weeks at a time, and the camera rotates the oldest recordings out automatically. If you're technically inclined, you could set up a Linux box with ZoneMinder and add other types of cameras to the mix later, whereas Dropcam doesn't offer that possibility. Dropcam scales poorly because the Internet connectivity must support constant streaming from all cameras. I had trouble with WiFi performance and video stream stutter with both types of cameras when I had multiple streams running from any sort of distance. If you can do so, run Ethernet to the cameras. For just one or two you should be fine with wireless.Support: I haven't needed Dropcam support yet because the product is pretty solid. The D-Link e-mail support is laughable and reminds me of the old DOS days when the solution to all problems was to reboot. If you find a firmware bug (I've found several), they just tell you to reset everything to factory defaults and try again. Once you do that, and find the bug again, you just have to cross your fingers that they fix it.Summary: If you are not technically inclined, it's hard to beat the ease of setup of the Dropcam HD. It just works with no fooling around and has a great web-based interface. If you are willing to tinker with the sittings directly through the onboard Web server, the D-Link cameras have more flexibility and no recurring cost.After living with my setup for over a year, I suggest setting up a micro recording server or NAS for centralized control. Beyond a few cameras it starts to get really cumbersome to have each camera mapped out through the router on its own port with its own SD storage. Also, if you have the cameras in your home and don't want to be bombarded with clips of yourself constantly, you'll find yourself unplugging the cameras and having to plug them back in. A centrally-managed setup with multiple profile such as Blue Iris would be less irritating.If you are willing to forego on-camera SD card storage, there are many IP cameras such as the ones from Dahua with much better image quality and night vision for not much more money. For stand-alone use of one or two, they're a decent value.The attached 10-second video is the longest that the camera will send via e-mail when it detects motion. It will simultaneously record up to 1 minute to the SD card, or record to the SD card 24/7.

Reviews.Title: Great for outdoor house security
Reviews.Author: Vamp
Reviews.Content: Using for: Outside- Residential Front and Backdoor security (wifi / IP)-Pros: Price, Easy Install (prior networking knowledge), Great Video Software, iPhone & brower viewing, Great night vision, Great quality video/picture, good frames per second-Cons: Power Cord length, No wind screen to prevent wind noise on Mic, If outside the sun conditions will ALMOST wash out the area in the direct sun (Sunrise/Sunset) But you can still make out faces. Midday is great otherwise. Viewing angle not the best for outdoors, but tolerable.--------------------------------------------------------I was looking for some security cameras for some time when I finally came across this IP(wifi) camera. The install CD takes you step by step on setting it up. (Plug this in, click continue, unplug this, etc). Had a few hickups, but it was my router settings.I bought 2 of these at an office supply store. One for the front yard and one for the backyard (how to weatherproof at very bottom of review). For the front yard I have it between my security door and my front door. So no one can tamper with the unit and my door is covered by a patio overhang. The powercord goes over the door and inside the house to an outlet (with an extension cord of course).I have both cameras set up to record (with included software on local PC) when it senses movement in designated areas. If you go to the cameras IP address on your local network you can get into the settings and have it email/text you images if it senses movement in more designated areas (different from the program). I have it text me 6 pictures of the movement 2 before and 3 after the movement. To have it text you, find your carriers email address that allows you to do this. IE: I use ATT so I have it send to xxxxxxxxxx@mms.att.net (x's denote your cell number). So you'll get a text instead of an email.I ran into one problem with the video feed lagging when I tried to watch both feeds at the same time on the software. I narrowed it down to the router channel it uses to transmit wifi signal. It was on 11 and I switched it to 1, worked like a charm. Both cameras are being viewed Highest resolution and quality and Frames per second.I tried this camera for the inside the house and it works better than as an outside camera. Definitly a great IP camera.(Optional Reading. DIY Weather proofing this camera)The backdoor I had to make it weatherproof and night vision to still work behind the plexiglass.- 2"x2"x4" plastic junction box (home depot)- Lexon (plexiglass) sheet- outdoor extension cord- gap filler (yellow can)First I cut the lexan to be the same size as the cover of the box. Drilled a hole in the bottom for the extension cord to fit into the box. Plugged the power supply from the camera and the extension cord inside the box. Used the gap filler to fill in the gab between the hole and the cord to make it weather proof (wait for it to cure). Put the entire powersupply cord inside the box and the camera ontop of it (had to remove the bracket on the back of the camera with a vice). Put the lexon glass ontop and screwed it in (there is a rubber gasket provided). Then clear silicon around the glass to further weather proof it. Now the camera is sitting flush with the plexiglass so the night vision IR doent bounce off the glass and back at it self. So it works perfectly for my application.

Reviews.Title: Lousy customer service, minimal Mac support, it works-barely
Reviews.Author: Richard L. Garrett
Reviews.Content: I've got four of these cameras, while they DO work, the technical support sends canned responses, the customer forum on mydlink.com is quick to ban any adverse product discussion, and the MAC BETA utility software has been beta since January 2011 and will not allow me to add cameras to mydlink.com. We'll see how the hardware performs but my first impressions are far from favorable. If you are a Macintosh user, beware, you are on your own.9/10/2011: A new Macintosh setup utility is available here: [....]Be persistent with customer service, I FINALLY got past the canned/programmed responses and got help in the form of a new setup wizard.

Reviews.Title: could not connect to wireless network
Reviews.Author: M. Leary
Reviews.Content: I spent a long time unsuccessfully trying to get this camera to connect to my wireless (b/g/n mixed) network.  Support is a joke, they seem to be only capable of reading their documentation back to me and nothing more.  The camera worked fine plugged into a wired network but that is not what I bought it for.  Based on my experience and reading other reviews, it seems that this camera has a really flaky wifi implementation that just refuses to work with certain networks.  I am an professional network administrator, so I should not have had any problem getting this working.  I have about 12 different devices on my home wifi network and have never had any problems with it.

Reviews.Title: Quite frustrating
Reviews.Author: liongate
Reviews.Content: The camera set up easily with only two calls to tech support, and I'm a computer tech so I'm surprised I had to call at all.  Remote viewing setup was achieved after the second call to tech support to find out I needed to install software from their website which I had to Google as he sent me to the wrong site. Their support seems to have a 3 minute window to close calls and they try to mark the issue resolved when it is not. I finally installed a third party software program to enable motion detection much better than their software did. Everything was fine until we had a power outage and the camera would not reconnect to the network. Dlink told me it was my wireless router and hurried me off the phone. It is not my router. The fourth tech I called told me I was typing in my IP address incorrectly when in fact the software should detect the network settings automatically and I know how to type in the ip address correctly.  He hurried me off the phone as well saying he would escalate my call to a tech who would call me back within the hour. I got a callback three hours later and the tech said he would send some setup program via email. I still don't have the app and the camera is still not networked. I think the camera is fine but their support is poor. I am going to choose another brand and chalk this up to a lesson learned.

Reviews.Title: DCS-942L as a burglar alarm
Reviews.Author: Dan Thomas
Reviews.Content: I got this item yesterday and immediately started to set it up.  I had compared this camera to the Foscam's and Dropcam and I bought this because of the wealth of information at the dlink site.  Also, it looked like it would fulfill my needs.I have an older router that doesn't support WPS.  WPS enables you to push a button on the router to set up the camera automatically.  I needed to physically connect the camera via the supplied Cat 5 cable to the router itself (not my PC).  But there is a label on the camera over the power and ethernet port that notifies you to install the CD first.The CD walked me through the installation process with no difficulty.  I then went looking to see if there is a firmware upgrade.  I found one on their site and downloaded it and browsed for it in the camera's web interface.  That didn't work and luckily it reverted back to the old firmware.If you have registered the camera with Dlink (I suggest registering), then the mydlink site will upgrade the firmware for you.  They also warn that the ethernet cable needs to be connected to the router, which I didn't do during the manual firmware upgrade.With the firmware upgraded, I moved the camera to the area that I wanted to monitor, then got the IP address of the camera from my router and pointed my tablet to that URL (use "https://) so that I could set the viewing area.I wanted it to e-mail me video clips when it detected motion, so I pulled my account data from the t-bird e-mail account settings and tested it.  The test sends a photo.Somewhere along the way I also set up network time protocol (NTP) and pointed it to Dlink's NTP site.  That way you get the correct time on the video within a few secondes.There are 4 different video recording/playback modes that you can set.  It actually captures video in all 4 modes at once.  For an e-mail of a video, you might want a little bit lower quality and resolution than if you are monitoring it in your own house over your wireless.  In fact, you can point Real Player at it and select which video mode you want to monitor (URL rtsp://<camera_IP_address>/mode)I put a 16 GB micro SD card in it so that the video would be permanently captured.  You can record to the SD card only when there is motion detected and this is a great option for setting up the motion detection.  You can then go through the captures (a little over a minute per capture) and make sure that recording only triggers on the events that you want.  In my case I set up for PIR motion detection only at low sensitivity, since I only want it to detect motion 5-15 feet away.  After reviewing some of the videos, it only triggers when one of us is walking through the room and not the ceiling fan.  It hasn't been through a thunder storm yet.When the camera detected motion, I wanted 2 things to happen:1. I would recieve an SMS text on my iphone at <my_phone_number>@txt.att.net2. My g-mail account would get a 10 second video.The text message would alert me to check the e-mailed video.  Unfortunately, it seems that you can't add 2 e-mail addresses in the e-mail setup.  Nor can you select both a video and a snapshot to be sent, one to one address and the other to another.  I got around this by setting up my g-mail account to forward the e-mail to my SMS text message account.  While I can't see the video in the text message, the text message informs me in no uncertain terms that motion has been detected.  Then I can revert to e-mail and watch the video.Other nice features are that you can set up a schedule when it will record to the SD card or send e-mails when it detects motion.  I haven't spent a lot of time playing with mydlink on their website, but it doesn't seem to be nearly as sophisticated as the camera's own web interface.  The thing to do might be to set up IP forwarding on the router as others have suggested and access the camera itself remotely.Maybe I will report back on it after I have some more experience with it.  But, for now and for the price, I am pretty happy7/30/2013 update.  We went through a terrific thunderstorm last night with lightning close by.  The only time the PIR detection triggered was when my wife walked past a couple of times.  Also, when you log out of the web interface and it warns you to close the browser, do what it says!  I was trying to permanently set its IP address on the router and couldn't get back into it with firefox.  I brought IE up and logged in.  I thought that I was going to have to figure out how to factory reset it.  Another good thing is that by default it responds to ping.

Reviews.Title: Love it!  Planning on purchasinig more.
Reviews.Author: W. L. Holder
Reviews.Content: This is perfect for me.  I am responsible for operations at a location 24/7, but obviously cannot be there all the time.  This is perfect for my needs, allowing me to keep an eye on the required spot from anywhere I happen to be.The picture quality is good, Ive seen better but this works great for being able to see what is going on.  For the price, I dont think you would find anything better.  The nighttime function is excellent, no compaints at all from me.  Provides clear images without the bright to dim flashing I have seen with other systems while in the dark.Being able to log in to the web site to check is the best part for me.  If I get a customer call about an issue, I can use my laptop and aircard to check it out from anywhere that I can get an aircard signal.Now that I have seen how handy this is, I plan on getting a couple more for other locations that I would to keep on eye on as required.  Pity my kids the next time they decide to have friends over while Im out!!The camera does have a light to let you know if someone is watching, which helps with 'morality' and privacy type issues that could arise with a wireless camera that can be watched over the internet.Overall, this is a great product, I am well impressed.

Reviews.Title: A little tedious (and spam list-y) but works fine
Reviews.Author: Soplos
Reviews.Content: It was a little difficult to get it set up.  The device would not communicate with the internet using a satellite service (Wild Blue), perhaps because of the latency.  Using FIOS there was no problem connecting, but the set-up screens would not properly save using M$ Internet Explorer nor Google Chrome ("Web Page Not Available").  It finally worked fine with Firefox, however.  Finally, 30 minutes after registering with D-Link so I could access the camera on the Internet I started getting spam on the email address I used, which had not been receiving spam before.  I have to say that I REALLY resented that.  But the camera works fine.  I get an email when the mailman arrives, and I can check who's at the front door with my iPhone.

Reviews.Title: Terrible wireless performance
Reviews.Author: Paul Anderson
Reviews.Content: I have owned and been very happy with two DCS-920's for the past year or so. One of them recently stopped working, so I decided to replace it with the DCS-930L. The 920 has an external WiFi antenna, and the 930L does not, so I was interested to see how strong the signal would be on the new camera.I received it and connected it to my D-Link DIR-628 wireless router and immediately noticed that the 930L's Signal(%) reading was about 30% and the transmitted image was very jerky - about one image every 2-3 seconds with complete freezes of 4-5 seconds. My 920, connected to the same router with the same image quality and size settings was showing 100% signal and streaming fluid video.  The 920, by the way, was also located twice as far from the router as the 930L. I actually moved the router so that it was within 10 feet of the 930L with a clear line of sight - and that only improved the Signal(%) value to about 60%.I called D-Link support and they had me upgrade the firmware for the 930L. That didn't improve things, so they told me it must be a hardware problem and gave me a support reference number and told me to return it. Amazon quickly shipped a new one which just arrived this afternoon. I set it up with the same D-Link router and am seeing exactly the same poor performance.So now I'll be returning two units instead of one. I'm very disappointed that D-Link would release a product that's so obviously broken. Perhaps if they'd added an external antenna, this would be a wireless video camera instead of a wireless camera that is only capable of "streaming" one picture every couple of seconds.

Reviews.Title: Lots Of Install Problems, Hideous Support
Reviews.Author: CPALawyer
Reviews.Content: Bought two DCS-942Ls.  The small 942L looks good, and it's nice to have built in IR illuminators.  The SD micro card slot is a good feature as well.  That's where the good ends.  I have 27 IP devices including 15 IP cameras on a three story home network, so I know more than the average consumer about configuring wired and wireless devices.  The 942L night vision is blurry and out of focus.  The day time video quality is low, and also out of focus, and after lots of tweaking the video quality is still crummy.  DLink's claimed easy to install is anything but.  The camera will not launch in explorer, but after much tweaking you might get it working.  Worst of all is the hideous technical support with 1 plus hour holds, and often after waiting so long for support when you get switched to a tech DLink disconnects, so start all over again!  If you can get to a tech, expect script reading with no resolution.  Overseas Dlink techs have a very bad attitude and are not happy.  So, if you have unlimited time and are willing to spend days trying and tyring to get it to work only to fail, then go for it.  Otherwise, buy something else.

Reviews.Title: doesn't work with Apple - macintosh
Reviews.Author: Bill S.
Reviews.Content: This product is really frustrating to use with an Apple or mac computer.  It will constantly ask you to do updates and after you do them, it will ask you to do them again.I've configured, gotten it to work, then they do updates to Java, and the whole thing falls apart again, and you have to go through some set of mystery steps to try to get it working again.  There are miles of suggestions over at the apple site.  Sometimes one of them works for some small subset of people but then the thing goes bonkers again when Oracle or Apple change anything.Do not recommend for apple users.Oddly, I have good luck with it, seeing it on my iphone, but you have to be able to access the camera on your laptop to make changes to the settings remotely.For the few periods of time that I've had it working, I really liked it a lot. But otherwise, a big ball of frustration.  There is NOthing about this that is plug and play for mac users.

Reviews.Title: Reasonable camera that works well for me
Reviews.Author: Steven Baker "Rock on!"
Reviews.Content: I needed a camera to keep an eye on our front porch.  Stupid kids in the neighborhood playing a few games so it was time to pull out the high tech gadgetry and bust 'em! After reading all the reviews on wireless cameras, watching YouTube videos, etc... I bought this camera.  I got it from radio Shack, which was a bit more than Amazon but I needed it quickly.I found the hints here to be helpful when setting up the camera.  I have a PC and an older Cisco router that does not have WPS.  Even still it was reasonable.  First put in the CD and run the wizard. Next set up the camera via cable (not wireless).  Get everything working, then exit the setup wizard.  Then start it again (leave the camera plugged in to the network) and configure your wireless network.  Once that is set up, then the camera worked first time on my wireless network.I searched the app store and downloaded the my dlink appl for the iPhone.  That works nicely, as does mydlink.com via the web.I shoved in a microSD card and set up the motion detection to record local video.  That was pretty easy too.So all in all, at least for my setup, it was up and running in about 30 minutes and I never had to call their support center.~Steve

Reviews.Title: FIX for "unable to detect internet connection" wtih DCS 930L D-Link Cam
Reviews.Author: Monica-MoniQue "MONiC"
Reviews.Content: FIX FOR: "cannot detect internet connection" upon unregistering and then re-registering.I had a nightmare trying to install because it would not recognize my internet connection even though I was connected perfectly to high speed internet.  Turns out the disk is not compatible with the part 2 of the installation when you must update the firmware.  After 3 hours and 2 techs at D-LINK to no avail, they were on an endless search of firewalls and other things that did not have anything to do with this problem, and searching online I finally found the fix and it works!  Here it is:Re: 930L wizard won't find my Internet connection« Reply #2 on: April 11, 2012, 06:10:38 PM »I had the same problem.  I had to unregister my camera because I was getting spammed with emails due to the motion detection being too sensitive.  The problem is that it seems the "new" installation wizard that is required if you have upgraded your camera to firmware 1.04, will not find an internet connection.  The "old" setup wizard on your original CD, sees your internet connection, but can't register the camera because it is upgraded... Catch 22!!To fix this you must downgrade your camera to v1.0 by downloading the old firmware here: [...]Select the DCS in the first dropdown, and then 930L in the second if you don't see a list of files.  The file you want to get is: Firmware: DCS-930L A1 FW v 1.00 (for ww).  This is the internal software that was loaded on your camera when it came out of the box.Download the bin file to your computer and then log in to the camera via the IP you have assigned to it: 192.168.xxx.xxx.* Go into Maintenance and "upgrade" to the old firmware that you just downloaded.  You can confirm that you're on the old version in the status tab.* Run the old set up wizard from your CD, and register to MyDlink (yay!!)* Go back into Maintenance in the camera admin panel, and upgrade your firmware back to 1.04.Now you should be back up and running!THANK YOU TO meebs A MEMBER ON THE D-Link forumRe: 930L wizard won't find my Internet connection« Reply #2 on: April 11, 2012, 06:10:38 PM »[...]

Reviews.Title: DLink DCS-930L wireless IP camera review
Reviews.Author: Scott Walker
Reviews.Content: I picked this unit because it does not require a base unit or anything else.  Connected it to my router to input my wireless network inforamtion.  Then simply installed in my wireless location of choice.  Easily connects to the inernet for live streaming video/audio while I am at work and also can view on my iPhone 4 with the "DLink Lite" free app.I saw a Youtube video of how it should be fine for outdoor use even though the manufacturer says nothing about using outdoors.  It is really supposed to be used indoors.  I put it outside anyway in a protected area and it works perfectly.  At night it works fine with my motion sensor flood lights so I can see anything moving in the darkness.Email alerts with still pictures are sent when motion is detected.  This camera works as epxected.  It does come with software to install on your home PC if you need to record video on a regular basis.  I am not using that piece because I just rely on my email snapshots from the motion sensor.I can see when packages are delivered and when neighbors come by while I am not home.  The audio is so good that I can hear neighbors outside talking three houses down from me.I did not run into any firewall or network problems like others have posted.  I am using a Netgear "G" router.  The camera supports both Wireless G and N.

Reviews.Title: Works awesome, surprised by all the negative reviews
Reviews.Author: XNOR
Reviews.Content: It literally took me less than 10 mins to set up this unit and get be fully working.Took it out of the box, connected to the LAN & PC, put the CD in the PC - configured the device and I was all set.  Just need to follow the instructions as given.What all did I test?  - Tested online with web:  Great video quality, not the jerky motion you see in gas station videos  - Tested with iPhone app:  Great video quality and easy to use AppWhat I did not like about this unit ?  - When connected over 3G - the reliability of the video was not that great, it would not get connected to the server all the time.Other than the issue with the iPhone connected over 3G - I had no issues with this and very satisfied with the wifi camera.

Reviews.Title: Finally, an HONEST Product....But WAIT!
Reviews.Author: USMC Combat Vet "Retired!"
Reviews.Content: UPDATE March 2012: U had put this away after just a week of use. Dug it back out to permanently set up and it worked for less that 15 minutes. Green light went off, hard reset did NOTHING....Knocking this to 1 star ans customer support has FAILED to even respond & the hoops you jump through to go NOWHERE with them is just too much. Buyer beware.________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________Original review below"After the utter FIASCO of trying out the Archerfish Solo 802.11 Wireless Intelligent Video Surveillance System with Built-In DVR ..... I was convinced any of these similar devices were pure crap. But this has not only turned me around but made me an enthusiast. THIS is how it is "supposed" to be done in my opinion.  NO hidden fees & costs. NO taking my credit card number for some SO CALLED FREE service!, NO problems our hours trying to troubleshoot and end up never getting installed. NO hours on the phone with tech support....Nope. This took less than 15 minutes, was almost as simple as plug- n- play, and woks. Just plain & simply works.  I can't address sending images to cell phones etc since my use is as a garage monitor & UPS lookout device. When it is hot I like to leave my garage door open and not worry about who enters to help themselves to my toys. I also want to know who is near my driveway so If my doorbell rings I know to answer it or if I am wasting my time dealing with some religious nut trying to save my soul...So my use is far from what the mainstream is I am sure. What I love is that this really allows me to do all I need and to even set "motion zones" with free software you download to add to this camera.  Plus It has the ability to record directly from the camera to a local hard drive, trigger motion detection, set recording schedules, set e-mail alert notifications, and even support for up to 32 cameras. Best part unlike my last nightmare with Archerfish, I can record video directly to a Network Attached Storage (NAS) device, eliminating the need for a dedicated computer to store video. You set up any "zones" where motion will trip recording with FREE software. THIS is how I wanted in the first place!  If you choose, you can have emails sent and configure this almost any way imaginable. Again, quick, clean and SIMPLE! No hidden fees, costs, traps or hassles. As a baby or Nanny cam, this would be amazing. In my case, I just have neighbors to worry about....The picture is nice for this price camera. Low light performance is good as well. I use it in wireless mode and no problems at all. It does require plugging into a wall socket to power so that is a consideration for camera placement. The camera also has a light that flashes when recording so that is nice as well for someone wondering about privacy? All in all, I am very grateful to have found this since I had given up after the last joke of a camera with Archerfish....

Reviews.Title: Don't waste your time - it's junk.
Reviews.Author: ITA
Reviews.Content: I read the reviews on this thing before I purchased, and decided to risk it anyway. Bad decision. This is everything everyone else complains about, and less. First off, the construction is cheap. I have several DCS-932L's, and the ball joint on those is metal. I guess D-Link decided to save money, and changed it to a piece of nylon junk. This joint feels very fragile in your hands, and doesn't seem to want to tighten up. I was fearful I would break it just trying to get it tight enough to hold the camera up. This camera also seems less stable on it's base than the 932L.Now came the fun part.... Since I already own several 932L's, I was already familiar with the setup, and MyDlink.Com. I noticed upon powering it up that the firmware was at v1.00. As an I.T. guy, I am always concerned about running the first version of anything. I noticed that the 942L didn't automatically ask about updating the firmware (like the 932L does). I decided to see if I could manually find it. The link in the help screen took me to a site that was in Chinese. Nice. When I went to the D-Link support site (U.S.) I couldn't find a firmware file anywhere. I finally googled it and found in on the MyDlink site. I updated the firmware to v1.01. Newer... but just barely. Maybe when they get to v 1.2 it will be better???The real headaches began when trying to make changes to the camera settings. Nine times out of ten, it would timeout during 'Saving', and display 'Page cannot be displayed' in IE. Obviously, there are issues with the built-in web part of the firmware. I spent about an hour trying to get it configured - no luck. It's going back. I will stick with all 932L's, they seem to work much better. Nice try D-Link, but you really missed the mark with this thing. It's a good thing I didn't buy this before the 932L's, or I would have been frightened off of the entire line.

Reviews.Title: This product does not work.  Do not purchase.  There is no support.  Please don't waste your time and money
Reviews.Author: S J Gilbert
Reviews.Content: This product does not do what it says it will.  I have yet to have one work.  Support is never available, and the wait is never less than 30 minutes even if you can figure out the menus.  This company should be embarrassed to produce and sell this product, and I am surprised the FTC even allows them to do so.  If you enjoy having your fingernails pulled out one by one, this product will be equally enjoyable.  I have been trying for months to get service, repair or return from DLink.  If you buy this product, you deserve what you get.

Reviews.Title: Another total junk from D-Link
Reviews.Author: Koorosh Beigian
Reviews.Content: Like many other D-Link products, setup is completely confusing and didn't work on my machine. Tech support had no idea what I was talking about once I got through to them (total waste of time). She recommended that I keep trying this on different computers and if it didn't work to just return the product.Save yourself the hassle I went through.

Reviews.Title: Set up and wifi problems
Reviews.Author: Corey Kaye
Reviews.Content: I purchased this cam specifically for the mydlink.com feature so I could view online from anywhere or on my phone.  The camera went through the entire set up process without a hitch until we reached the step where it connects to mydlink.com, and it would not connect.  Spoke with customer support--they could not determine the cause and issued an RMA.  The replacement camera had exactly the same issue, so I set up port forwarding with a dyndns.com account...and the replacement camera could not pick up my wifi signal in the area I'd like to view (the original camera picked up the signal fine in that location.)  Sent the second camera back and am going to try the Foscam.This might be a great camera IF you can get one that doesn't have setup/connection problems.

Reviews.Title: Think before you buy if your port 80 is occupied or unavailable
Reviews.Author: Stephen K. Chu "Zdfun"
Reviews.Content: Note: this review is for those port 80 is unavailable.It should be easy to setup if your port 80 is available. However, mine doesn't.I emailed to D-Link tech support and see if they have any solution, first, they replied and just told me to use another port, that is! No further info. Then I email them again, explained what I had done, and I could see it using the IP address:port from the browser, but i couldn't see anything in mydlink.com and the iphone app. And I got one simple reply: "if the iphone app doesn't work, remove it and reinstall again."Here is the solution:If your port 80 is not available, then you CANNOT use mydlink.comAnd you also CANNOT use iphone app DLINK LITE.You have to change the port in the camera page in a web browser,for example if your camera's ip is 192.168.0.100, and you change the port to 81, then you must access to your camera 192.168.0.100:81From outside, you need to type your home IP address ( I prefer to use DYNDNS.ORG ), so the address is yourname.dyndns.org:81For Iphone user, you have to use the app calls DLINK CAM to view the camera because this app allow you to enter your IP and port.For all user: there is no reason to call DLINK tech support except you want someone to piss you off, Google is the best tech support.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera, but going back - Beware D-Link registration
Reviews.Author: SDDJD
Reviews.Content: The camera setup was straightforward enough.  The cd-rom contained in the package would not read, but the current setup software is available readily enough via D-Link's website.Once the camera was connected, the setup "wizard" (really only a front page with no explanations) appeared.  The camera configuration options were clear enough, as were the more detailed network options (nice features).  However, to a buyer with limited understanding of various network settings this might be a hurdle.The single overriding failure of this entire product is the ridiculous method of accessing the Mydlink service.  In order to create a Mydlink account one must register the product and receive an email confirmation. Simple enough, except that a giant like D-Link apparently can't set up a reliable email registration system on a par even with my own small biz.Two days of repeated attempts to register yield only the "thank you for... a confirmation email will be sent shortly."  There is NO other means to get past this page, and no email ever arrives.  Essentially the product is dead in the water unless you're purchasing to view within your own network.  Of course, this camera is touted as a streamlined way to REMOTE view.D-Link support:  What can I say that hasn't been said.  Emails to support at D-link were confirmed by email receipt, and also promised a response "shortly".  Interesting that THAT email received a reply btw.  The dreaded phone call to the support hotline yielded the following advice:1. Use the setup cd that came with the product.  Thanks, never would have thought of that.2. The registration system is sensitive to caps, try all lower case.  Yes, you read that right- this technological giant's registration supposedly chokes on caps in the registration info.  Incidentally, repeating the reg in lower case had no effect.3. Try an alternate email address; also no effect other than the joy of now checking two email accounts for mail that isn't there.Bottom line, it's appalling that what appears to be a very nicely made and functional product is going to be returned because a registration system that could have been programmed to work efficiently by any fifteen year-old can't activate buyers' accounts.I'll be returning this product "shortly".

Reviews.Title: Admended review
Reviews.Author: W. Hinegardner
Reviews.Content: Camera works well, but the set point for switching between day (color) and night (b/w) is set to high. The camera stays in b/w 90% of the time unless there is direct sunlight shinning into the room. Ther does not appear to be any way to adjust this setting.2/29/12: Returned the camera. Cound not get the motion sensor to work at all. Tried every combination in the limited instructions and could not get any of them to work.  Found a number of similar complaints on the Internet about the same issue. Neither the video or snapshop mode would work.  Added to the poor day/night sensitivity the camera was not worth the price paid.

Reviews.Title: No Customer Service Support
Reviews.Author: Cherie L. Lacy
Reviews.Content: I purchased one of these cameras to keep an eye on things at my house remotely when I travel.  It works well and therefore, I ordered a second one to monitor the sump pump in my basement.  Unfortunately, I am unable to run both cameras to run off the same account.  When I tried to contact d-Link to get help with this problem I received an auto-reply which has yet to be responded to almost two weeks later.  I have tried calling customer support and both times was on hold for over 15 minutes before I finally gave up.  No doubt there is some way to run multiple cameras in a home setting from the same account, but I'll be darned if I can figure it out.  And, thanks to D-Link, I'm left on my own to do just that.  An expensive paper weight!

Reviews.Title: cheap for a reason
Reviews.Author: vulcan
Reviews.Content: freeze up a lot,but you can see general picture.sound even worse - practically no sound just some noise on the back

Reviews.Title: Wireless does not work with Linksys router
Reviews.Author: Carlos J. Parra "netosphere"
Reviews.Content: Just for background, I am a savvy electronics user and I have configured several devices with load balancers, port forwarding etc. And I haven't been able to set up this camera with my router (Cisco-Linksys WRT54G2 Wireless-G)... I created a hot-spot with my cell phone and it did work, and also with the LAN cable (wired internet access).According to the specifications of the camera it can support B N and G networks... My router supports G and B connections and I have never had an issue with other devices.I don't have any special characters in my Network name or any non-standard configuration, just plain cable modem, wireless router and this D-Link DCS-932LI don't recommend it. The picture is also very small since it has a low resolution, but it does work in the dark.Go ahead and get something better.

Reviews.Title: Great Cameras
Reviews.Author: Brian Wayne Rairden
Reviews.Content: I have 4 of these.  32gb card gets you almost 8 days of constant recording.  Most recent firmware update has everything working well.  I have all macs, iphones and ipads.  As of the last update, all features are working with all of them.  I can't comment on the 2 way audio, because I don't have speakers connected to them.  But the microphone icon is there on the ipad and iphone mydlink app.The mac support by dlink is greatly improving.  If you are the slightest bit tech savvy, you won't have too much of a problem.TIP:  If you have an ipad or phone and want to view recordings remotely, make sure you are recording in MPEG mode.

Reviews.Title: Great Wireless Camera
Reviews.Author: B. Dawson
Reviews.Content: I got this camera a week or so ago (for $40 on here).  Hooked it up and it works like a charm.  I am an IT professional so setup was easy to me but I can see it being a problem for some people.  I have two WRT54G routers with DD-WRT (one as an AP and one as a Repeater) and the video is smooth and I can access the camera from anywhere with a little Port Forwarding.  Connect it via Ethernet cable first and do the initial setup and then you can setup the wireless and detach the Ethernet.  The wireless strength is not the best so make sure you have a router not too far away.  The Android app works great as well.  The camera sends pictures to my Gmail account upon motion detection and this feature rocks.  Someone has stolen packages off my porch and I hope this will deter them or the thief will be caught soon :)

Reviews.Title: D-Link DCS 932 L Wireless Day/Night Home Network Camera
Reviews.Author: S. Allen "Shewolf"
Reviews.Content: // To view this video download Flash Player (version 9.0.115 or higher)'); } } catch(err) { fp_resizePlayerSpace('cv_moCDQSO9KSMF5Z', 0, 0); } return false; } function _cv_moCDQSO9KSMF5ZloadSwf(movieID, playerVersion) { var swfLocation = "http://g-ecx.images-amazon.com/images/G/01/am3/20120510035744301/AMPlayer._V148501545_.swf"; Reviews.Title: Good baby monitor, but requires some effort to setup
Reviews.Author: Andrew Sterling Hanenkamp
Reviews.Content: I purchased this device to use as a baby monitor to replace a wireless camera we bought at a garage sale whose DC plug was starting to short out. Based upon my experience with audio and video baby monitors, I can tell you that both the audio and video quality of this is device is excellent. The day mode color is great. The night mode is nice and bright, the infrared LEDs easily shine bright enough for the camera to be placed 6-8 feet away (much better than the previous infrared video camera I had which had to be right next to the crib). The audio is great. I see some folks complaining about static or other issues, but the only static I hear on the audio is from the white noise machine in the baby's room. When that's off, the audio is not perfectly silent but pretty good for a cheap webcam mike.Setup was not difficult for me, but I used to be a systems administrator and maintain my own home network and have a custom-built phone system. Setting up this camera is not quite what I would call "Do-It-Yourself" for the typical home owner with a wifi network. To set it up, you have to plug it into your network using an ethernet cable (provided) first. You then run the setup software. I mostly use Apple computers and the CD did not come with Apple software, so I had to go their web site, navigate the web site to the support page, find the software and download it (that was a chore all by itself).The setup software worked once installed, but again had some problems because it had to upgrade the firmware and then I had to get a different version of the setup software running to setup the camera, which was a little weird. Once I did that, it detected the camera and setup the mydlink account with very little effort. However, it does nothing to help with the rest of the setup, like turning on the wireless. There's no helpful wizard or instructions on how to use the camera as a wifi device (which is not even turned on by default). To do that, I had to click around and figure out how to get to the Advanced Settings myself and then look around those and set it up to use the wifi network. The settings look very much like what you'd expect if you have set up a D-Link or similar router, but, again, not something I'd expect a typical home owner with a wifi network to operate.As with so many computer electronics hardware, the manufacturer has spent a most of the time developing this product focused on the hardware. The device looks attractive, the base is stable, the camera itself is of sturdy construction, and the components, while cheap, do the job and work well together. The software, on the other hand, is clunky and inconsistent. The various viewers all support different features, which just a little strange. Even the Java applet for viewing it online versus the Java applet for viewing it locally have different features. You can take a screenshot from the iPad, but you can't from the Java applets on the PC. There are two different Android applications, one is Free and one costs $0.99, but they don't really tell you what the difference is (the $0.99 seems to be tablet oriented while the Free one seems to be phone oriented, but they are almost like different apps for doing the same thing with completely different UIs). I have not tried the ActiveX control for using the camera, but I suspect that it is yet again different from the Java applet. The setup utility is badly documented in certain places. For example, do you want to know what motion detection will do when turned on? You'll just have to guess because I don't know and nothing I've found in the app, in the manual, or on the D-Link web site says what it does. I don't need it, so I don't really care, but seems like it ought to at least tell me what its good for if I think I might.I very much like the fact that it supports Android, iPad, Apple, and PC and accessing the camera remotely from the mydlink web site. This is wonderful. The fact that it supports remote access is even better. This to me is the killer feature of this device. However, one does need to be a little careful. If you are at home on your home network, do not use the mydlink web site to watch the camera. Go directly to the camera (which might require figuring out what IP address your camera is assigned). I found that with just 2 systems watching the camera (a laptop and an iPad), my internet connection slowed to a crawl and I have a pretty big 12 Mbps downlink, which means it was sucking up a huge chunk of my bandwidth. I fixed the problem by using my in-house DNS server to assign the system a name and setting up user accounts, so my wife can now login to view the camera by sending her browser over to (...), actually that's not the name I used, but you get the gist). The iPad will still use the mydlink site, but that's tolerable since its just one device--however, I write web and mobile device software for a living and this does not need to be the case, it should detect and use the local camera feed if on the same network.Overall, I'd say you get what you pay for. If you're expecting image and sound quality that knocks your socks off, why are you paying $100 or less for this camera? You need something at least 2-times this price to get the kind of CCD and microphones capable of producing better quality. This is essentially a glorified a security camera. The goal is not image or sound quality. However, having easy access everywhere once its setup from a variety of devices is just incredible for this price point. People giving this 2 stars, in my opinion, is applying a $500 device expectation to a $100 device.I give it 4 stars because of: (1) marketing it as a DIY install, which I think is a pretty stretch given the effort required to set it up, and (2) because of the mediocre software and web site. Fix either of these, and I give it 5 stars. I'd actually take away a star for each of those, but for the fact that it supports Android, iPad, iPhone, PC, and Mac and has a web site for getting access to the camera from anywhere. That takes a lot of effort to accomplish, so I will give an extra star. If they fixed those two problems, I would ask Amazon to tack on a 6th star.

Reviews.Title: Airport extreme setup
Reviews.Author: Matt Shaw
Reviews.Content: I read a few reviews about problems with Mac:I have a Macbook Pro and Airport extreme router. No problems with setup... The auto-setup that the instructions talks about will not work. Connect the camera to your router and use the Dlink app to set up the camera. Then go the the Dlink site and enter the advanced setup. The instructions do a great job of outlining these steps.Some reviews mentioned problems with wireless setup:The camera must be wirelessly configured while connected to the Airport extreme. In the advance setup for the camera, enter the SSID of your wireless network, then enter the password for the router. Mark sure your wireless security protocol is correct and then save. You should then be able to disconnect the network cable and let the camera auto connect.Problems with audio:In the advanced setup you can adjust the audio gain...mine works fine. Lots of audio clipping until I adjusted...

Reviews.Title: What You'd Should Expect For the Cost
Reviews.Author: Jim
Reviews.Content: Easy installation, wireless works fine. Lots of software options for network/picture setup. Video quality compares to a $10 web cam. Picture quality is poor in lower light situations; bright sunlight it's acceptable, but the lower the light gets the worse the picture gets. In the house during the day produces lousy video quality.Power supply cable is WAY too short which limits placement of the camera.IR mode is nice, usable video in a pitch dark room. Audio is unusable because of static/clicking noises as other reviewers mentioned. Fortunately you can configure the audio to OFF. Five stars for the wireless/setup/software but one star for the camera.

Reviews.Title: Bugs
Reviews.Author: Kendra Schulz
Reviews.Content: Hate it, After trying to set up the camera for over a week off and on I finally got it to show the picture on both of my computers. Then trying to set up the motion dection was a nightmare. Mostly it takes pics of nothing and when somebody walks by it misses the shot. If I increase the sesitivity to more than 15% it floods my inbox. Not worth the trouble...

Reviews.Title: Just when you think it works...
Reviews.Author: Disappointed
Reviews.Content: Set this up when I bought it in May 2013.  I set it up to work wirelessly and everything worked great until the end of July 2013.  One day I went to fire up the mydlink app on my phone and it said the camera wasn't available.  No problem, I thought, I'll just go and unplug/reboot the camera we'll be all set.  Came back on, connected to my network again and the light went green.  Problem solved, right?  Wrong.  5 minutes later the camera was unavailable again.Being an IT professional, I figure there must be a firmware update for the camera or something to that effect, so I go out and update the camera to the newest version as magically I can still access the camera on my wireless network, it's just not communicating with the dlink site to display the image.  Same problem still occurs.  At this point I have no option but to call Dlink support.Talk about a hassle and a half.  After specifically being transferred to another department because "they handle the support for this particular camera" (means it must be a very special camera right?) I was put on hold for 30 minutes.  I had enough time to cook dinner for my family and sit down to eat before support came on the line.Then it was 30 minutes of troubleshooting at which point they told me I needed to plug the camera directly into the router to continue troubleshooting.  Why?  I bought this solely so I could use it wirelessly, obviously it's not working with wifi.  This was no small task as I had mounted this camera up high near the ceiling in my newborn's room.  I finally did a couple days later and called them back, and still nothing changed after another 45 minutes of troubleshooting tasks.  Finally I demanded to talk to the person's supervisor at which point she informs me she had just received authorization to RMA the product and send me a new one.  How convenient.Bottom line is I will never buy Dlink products again.  Got burned with a router a few years back, and now this defective piece of junk.  You will fall in love with it (if it works initially) out of the box.  But we warned, after much searching/troubleshooting on the internet, plenty of people are completely unsatisfied with the wireless capability of this device.  No thanks!

Reviews.Title: Returning camera
Reviews.Author: IgS
Reviews.Content: This camera is not very suitable for surveillance/security purposes, but may be good for a teenager interested to learn how stuff works. Installation requires using CD and upgrading firmware.  Configuring wireless access requires some knowledge of networking at the intermediated level.  There are some bugs, eg, could not configure the camera to record video on microSD, although emailing videos worked (there is a discussion of video recording issues on the site "forums.dlink com"). The camera arm is flimsy and doesn't hold camera in place; constant hissing background noise and no usable sound; occasional clicking noise (switch?) from the camera. Motion detection appears can't be adjusted for sensitivity, and camera will flood your email account with snapshots or videos, even when selecting low sensitivity and short time intervals. D-Link makes very good routers, but I was disappointed with this camera. Returning camera.

Reviews.Title: Not worth the effort - Junk!
Reviews.Author: Tim Malone
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera from Staples in my city. They really didn't know much about it. Upon getting it home, I found out that to do wireless I had to have WPS on my router, which I did not. Then it told me that it could do a wireless connection but would first need to be connected via ethernet. I did this only to waste another 20 minutes waiting for it to connect. In the end, an hour and a half later, the camera would not connect to my wireless network. Funny, because I have a wireless printer that works great, no muss, no fuss. I pugged it into the wall, gave it my wireless network credentials and it just worked.I work with web development and coding and found this unit to extremely difficult to get to work. I bring this up only to say that I am not computer/technology illiterate. In the end I went ahead and connected via ethernet. When I attempted to create my dlink account through the installer, it hurled. I went directly to the dlink site and it would not send a verification email to my gmail account. It told me to try another email account.In the end, there were too many compromises for me to even want to use this camera. Not to mention if the "easy" setup was this flawed, then I wasn't sure that my camera would be secure on dlink's site. They seemed to have numerous issues that did not instill confidence. I fear that my camera feed would not be secure.Too bad this camera didn't work because this was a good idea.

Reviews.Title: Dissappointing performance and no scheduled motion detection
Reviews.Author: zablalbaz "zab"
Reviews.Content: I suppose for the purpose of being able to open a web browser and view my children with their babysitter, it does an ok job.  Not great and the frames/second could be a bit more, but still usable.  That, however, is all I the good I have to say about this camera.  After playing around with it and upgrading the firmware, I have decided to purchase a different camera for the remainder of my setup at home.Here are the issues I have chosen as the most disappointing to me:1.  The wireless antenna range is just not that good. I have two access points at either side of my home providing complete coverage.  Every other wireless device and camera in the household is able to attach to the APs and obtain IP addresses.  This camera needs to be within 20-30 feet of an AP to work. I have a two year old smart phone and an ancient PDA that do better.2.  The audio is horrible.  Doesn't matter what browser/device I use to watch the stream.3.  And most importantly to me - there is no ability to set the camera up via its integrated firmware menu to do motion detection on a scheduled basis.In the setup menu I can set up a schedule where pictures are taken at regular intervals during specific times of the day. OR I can set up motion detection to snap pictures and send them out whenever motion is detected.  BUT I cannot have motion detection on a schedule at certain times of the day.  Why is this bad?  Because when motion detection is on, it is ON all the time. Including when I may be at home moving around in front of the camera.  And when it detects motion, it takes A LOT of pictures.  If the camera is set up to email the pictures somewhere offsite, the traffic can flood the network or spam an email account offline. In my opinion a good wireless camera should include a scheduled motion detection feature that can be enabled WITHIN its integrated firmware menu.For these reasons I give this webcam an overall rating of 1 star.  I'm not sure at this point if I can send it back since I have had it so long.  I'll try.  If not, then it will remain a "nanny cam" until such a time that D-Link sees fit to add the functionality for scheduled motion detection.

Reviews.Title: Does not work wireless
Reviews.Author: Al
Reviews.Content: I have been trying to get this to work wireless for 4 weeks. Will work for 2 to 3 minutes then nothing but a black screen. Works great when hardwired to the router but wirelessly does not. I have been troubleshooting this with Dlink tech support for the past 4 weeks and having to do the same thing time and time again, still no go. And the response I get is call back later. They don't know how to support the products they sell and will not honour the warranty. Their solution leave it hardwired. I purchased the device based on the advertised wireless capabilities and it fails, solution offered by Dlink tech support, hardwire it and they will not honour the warranty.

Reviews.Title: completely a mess
Reviews.Author: Tara Levy
Reviews.Content: I bought 2 d-link wireless routers before because of its low price. Both of them turn out to be bad buy.Problems:- wireless network intermittently dropped. In the craziest day, I had to reboot it 8 times.- one with signal booster was also a big failure, it didn't work at all.- Netgear, Linksys are way better.This product continues D-Link's legacy- WPS connection worked, router recognized it. However the setup wizard stuck in the camera searching and I can't create a d-link account, which makes it completely useless- I tried with both Windows and Mac versions, same problem.- OK... I tried the ethernet cable setup approach, setup wizard can't even find the cable connected camera.D-Link is an amazing company, rolling out s*** like products tirelessly.

Reviews.Title: Could be nice but works horribly
Reviews.Author: R. Morris
Reviews.Content: First, it's possible that maybe I just got a dud. However, from reading other reviews, it seems I'm not alone. I could replace this camera with another, but instead, I'll get a refund and search for another model. Still, the features I could see looked nice, even if they weren't able to actually work. Here are some problems I faced. * After being on for a few minutes, the camera would lose network connectivity, forcing me to restart it (by unplugging the power) to make it usable again. I'm not sure if this depends on what type of scene it is aimed at or not, but it definitely wasn't going to work for me.* The device was never able to find my wireless network--or any others, for that matter. I had to use the wired connection. This was not a configuration issue on either end. Even after a reset and making sure my network was in the 2.4 GHz bands of 802.11n (and b/g), this camera could not find it--or any of my neighbors' that my computer can also see. My SSID contained only letters, no spaces or symbols.The above made it pretty useless for me. However, here are a few good things about it that I was able to discover:* You do not need to use D-Link's software to set up or manage the camera. There is a Web interface. You'll just need to find the camera's IP address and view it in a Web browser (you can do the same with most network printers, for example). If you don't know how to do this, however, you might be better just using their software. The one on the CD only works with Windows. Some of their cameras have Mac versions available on their website; I didn't care enough to look since you don't need it.* You don't *have* to use D-Link's cloud/MyD-Link service. However, again, if you're not comfortable setting up your own alternative, you might want to. What I did (with great difficulty given how finicky the camera was) was set up an FTP server on my home LAN for a file share I could access with a username and password I used just for this purpose. You can configure the camera to upload images via FTP. (You can also do e-mail if you provide SMTP server info.) I didn't want to expose this publicly, which is fine for the camera itself since it's also on my LAN. To view when I was away, I VPNed (via a separate service I configured) into my home LAN and then connected to the file share. Obviously, an off-site solution would be better, but this is the best I could do. And of course, the average person will not want to do this--but I just wanted to note that you don't *need* D-Link's offerings. You can save either on a timer (every 'x' seconds) or via motion detection. I was never able to get motion detection to work before the camera crashed.* For remote viewing of the camera live, I'd rather go via the previous method of images the camera saved (not quite live but close), but I could also use the camera's Web interface and view either a still image (refreshing as needed) or launch a Java applet that would give real-time video (and audio, though of questionable quality). Sometimes starting the Java applet crashed the camera, however, and made me reboot it.Besides the things i mentioned first, there are a couple more bad things:* As far as I can tell, the camera can't actually save video, only images. You can configure how many/how often, but this still caught me off guard that I could only get a folder full of JPEGs.* Reset button is very hard to press (paper clip was too big; I needed to use SIM card tool), and WPS button is very easy to press. I suspect most people won't need to reset as much as I did, and WPS wasn't a big deal for me because WiFi didn't work for me on it anyway (though I'd rather set it up manually in any case), but I did accidentally press it a few times.The camera itself is fairly lightweight, and the base should mount (bring your own adhesive or whatnot) to flat surfaces if you want. You can manually move the camera a bit on the stand, but there is no pan or tilt functionality in the software.This camera could at least be decent if it worked better--the feature set isn't bad, and the hardware, while light, feels good. Importantly, image quality was also good enough for security purposes as far as I was able to tell. Unfortunately, the unstable firmware on the device itself made it unusable for me, and I am looking into other options.

Reviews.Title: Great Product for the price and great Tech Support from the company
Reviews.Author: Michael S.
Reviews.Content: This is a very easy way to watch your house and the set up is very easy. I had to get  Daniel (Tech Support for D-Link AR0042332) to get me into the correct website for the WiFi set up but I was not on the phone for more than ten minutes total and the system with 4 cameras was up and running streaming to my computer, IPad and IPhone.  Great way to protect your home inside and out.

Reviews.Title: Inferior quality compared to DCS-920
Reviews.Author: crankyoldman "crankyoldman"
Reviews.Content: I bought a pair of DCS-920s in mid-2010 and was quite pleased with their performance and value.  In Nov 2012 I needed a third camera so came back to Amazon to get another 920.  None were available but the 930L was listed as the "new model", so I ordered one.  While D-Link may consider it a replacement, it is inferior in very important ways.First, it is significantly lighter; the construction is all light plastic (including the base) so it is not as stable sitting on a ledge/shelf - The hanging power cord can drag it and if you add an ethernet cable be prepared to secure the camera in place.Next, it is fixed focus.  You can manually adjust the focus on the 920.  With the 930 you get a fixed focus lens similar to the old 110 point-and-shoot cameras.Even with these limitations, I was able to find a use for it.  At least until the third, and most important inferiority happened: The camera died at just under 9 months of use.So, the 930L is functional in some cases.  I didn't have a set-up problem as I did it all manually.  But it is not just inexpensive, it is cheap.  I'm exploring other manufacturers for a replacement.

Reviews.Title: Camera died - DLink no help
Reviews.Author: C. O.
Reviews.Content: So we set up the camera which was fairly easy.  Confirmed we could monitor it via the DLink web site which worked fine as well.  20 days after arriving, the camera would no longer power up.I contacted DLink via email and received no response for days - only to get a note saying please call tech support.  I tried calling and got continuous on-hold "please use our web site, our tech support staff are busy" messages.  Since it was within Amazon's return period I just boxed it up and sent it back.So, bad camera, bad customer service.  Can't say this product was a winner...

Reviews.Title: reliability is questionable
Reviews.Author: Larry J. Moon "spaceman"
Reviews.Content: this camera failed from overheating I suspect.  got an RMA from Dlink to return at my cost for shipping.  Received the replacement unit from Dlink and could not perform setup on the camera.  have given up trying to get dlink technical support on the line to help me troubleshoot the replacement camera.  was on hold three time for over thirty minutes and gave up finally.  am not going to spend another 7 dollars to send a defective camera back to them again.  I can buy another new one when on sale for less than 35 dolalrs.  i have two other dlink cameras same model no. that are still working fine so must have just gotten two lemons.

Reviews.Title: Mac Users Be Forewarned
Reviews.Author: MG
Reviews.Content: These appear to be reasonable cameras with fairly good resolution given the low cost. The mydlink system is, however, a complete nightmare for Mac users. There is very sketchy advice and troubleshooting for Macs and the Java runtime environment repeatedly fails making it impossible to see what your camera records. Add to that a pretty shoddy iPhone app and you have a nice camera recording footage you cannot see. I am really considering sending the whole thing (I bought several) back because it is unbelievably laborious to have to spend extensive time figuring out what the Java problem du jour is with the mydlink connection. I literally have my java console tracking logs constantly now because of this poor connection with their applet for the cameras. There are also additional quirks like the setup wizard for Mac allows the camera to install with recording of avi vs. mp4 (iPhone especially cannot peruse footage in avi) and a dozen other little things you have to setup. Sometimes a camera just seems to stop connecting and I have to reset it from scratch, meaning that I set all those little things all over again. :( I'm not sure if there is a more Mac friendly camera system out there, but what I can say is, the average Mac user is likely to be pretty frustrated with these products. You have to be very familiar with how to access your Java preferences and have a good knowledge of testing your browsers. BTW, Chrome users who are on the Mac OS should know this camera viewing system will not work in Chrome, because Chrome 20+ doesn't work with the 64-bit Java app on the Mac OS.

Reviews.Title: Utterly useless; won't connect or configure.
Reviews.Author: Loomis42
Reviews.Content: I bought one of these cameras at Radio Shack and it connected and still works perfectly. Since then I've tried 4 (four) other DCS-930L cameras and all have had issues. In fact I cannot get them to connect at all. The wizard simply doesn't recognize them. I've tried everything from upgrading firmware to altering router settings to unplugging everything except the device I'm working with. Customer support is useless. Like others have said they only know how to read the generic troubleshooting. Oddly, the only thing that seems to work is the original camera. I've even saved its settings and tried loading them to the new cameras manually. Nothing works for the new cameras. I'm about to sell them all to look for something better.

Reviews.Title: This grandma set it up in 3 hours.
Reviews.Author: Rhonda Mills "rhonda mills"
Reviews.Content: I was so happy that I'm able to receive emails with 6 pictures of motion detect. I did have to set the sensitivity level to lower because my mom can't hear and had the tv turned up loud and it would send me pics of nothing down the hallway. It connected instantly by wifi to my router. Love it. We are going to the beach and people have keys to house. So I can see if anyone goes in or out of bedrooms.

Reviews.Title: It's ok but needs improvement
Reviews.Author: John
Reviews.Content: After following the plug and play instructions to the letter, I ended up having to use my IT knowledge to install my cameras and get them working on my Verizon wireless router.  IT guy here.  I could imagine that any brand wireless camera that needs to get married to your wireless access point could present similar problems, or if installing using a wired Ethernet connection, so I'll withhold poor marks to Dlink but this is something they could improve upon.I bought two of these.  The first one is still working after about 6 weeks.  I just had to return the second one because something came loose from inside around the lens area and it caused the picture to have a permanent shadow on the left hand side of the viewing screen.  I tilted the unit sideways and the obstruction seemed to slip out of the way.  Possibly heat from staying on 24x7 caused something to detach, maybe a piece of film?  Strange because the camera was set up in an area that gets no traffic so I know nothing hit it.  I returned it to Radio Shack and sadly, the only one they had to replace it had a nylon mount which connects the camera onto the swivel base.  I can already tell this is not going to reliably hold the camera in place and I wonder why they went from the older mount which was made from either metal or hard plastic with chrome over it to this poor design.  Or, this was the earlier design.  Either way, I will be calling customer support to ask for a sturdier one.Though you could tie into your router and connect to the cameras directly, I went the easy route of creating a "My Dlink" account on the Dlink web site and thus the video/audio is streamed there in order to viewed from my iPhone, laptop, remote PC, etc.  I have noticed that sometimes the cameras will mysteriously not show up on my account as active.  This means you can't see the video feed.  Give it an hour or two and it may come back, or it may require a reboot of the camera.  This is frustrating if you are away from home.These are my first wireless IP cameras that I have dealt with.  Note something I missed, and that is that the video is in black and white.  It does the job though and I really don't have any complaints about the resolution.  The infra-red video is impressive, even in total darkness.  I was pleasantly surprised that I could see everything in total darkness.  (I mostly use an iPhone to monitor).I use a Mac Pro which comes with Safari for the web browser.  I gave up trying to update everything, install Active X or Java or whatever else it was that seemed to be a road block to be able to even manage the cameras on Dlink's web site in my "My Dlink" account.  I finally ended up downloading Firefox's browser and using this browser for the Dlink monitoring and adjusting settings remotely or from inside the house.The motion detection feature has been useless to me on both cameras.  It's really cool to sit there and use the interface to draw the area of the screen that you want to be monitored for movement but here's what I got on both cameras as a result.  The camera will email you either a 6 second video clip or a still.  I found that even on the least sensitive setting, using an area of the screen that just cannot move, it still falsely detected motion and flooded my inbox with clip after clip after clip.  If you're really bored, this might be cool but if you only want to know when there truly is movement, this will quickly become annoying.The audio is very impressive.  I found that I could hear conversations in the other end of my house.There is a timeout on the My Dlink site that will disconnect you from your session after a certain amount of time.  This means that you must continue to log back in and connect in order to keep seeing the video stream.  Not a problem if all you want to do is check in and see if the kitties are all good but annoying if you want to monitor for a while.I paid $149 at Best Buy and then $139 at Radio shack for the second one.  For what I got, I would much rather have paid around $65-$75 so I'm going to say that I find these a little expensive for what you get and I say this just from cost to benefit standpoint, not in comparing them with other brands and models.I think if I bought a third camera I would be tempted to try another band.  However, I have gotten used to the little iPhone app that requires only two taps to be watching the house from a remote location.  I am sure that you can't get other manufacturer's cameras rounded up with the Dlink cams in the My Dlink app.I probably would not have even written a review but the cheap nylon mount was a disappointment.  I believe I rated everything else fairly though.Good luck

Reviews.Title: Works!
Reviews.Author: Papia Roy
Reviews.Content: I bought 4 of these. The configuration wizard requires you to connect the camera directly to your router using an ethernet cable (supplied). As you progress through the configuration, there is a screen which asks you to choose whether you would like to use the camera using wired ethernet or a wireless connection. My advice is to select "wired" the first time you set up the camera; the "wireless" setting did  not work for me (the camera failed to be registered at the My Dlink site, which needs to happen for you to log in later to remotely view the video feed, if you choose to do it this way).After the registration goes through, log in to view the feed. At this point, the DLink website asked to update the camera firmware. After the firmware update, I was able to see the video feed.  At this point I logged out of the DLink site and re-ran the configuration wizard to change the connection method to "wireless". (Do not hit the "reset" button at the end of this process).

Reviews.Title: I wish I had bought more!
Reviews.Author: Sherif M. Latif "SML"
Reviews.Content: Fantastic product, easy setup, no hassles.  I can't say enough good things about this product.  I bought it to watch my dog while I'm away at work/keep an eye on my apartment.  I'll be honest, reading all the negative reviews I almost didn't buy it.  I will say two things: 1) I don't own a MAC 2) I have a desktop computer with a WIRED internet connection that I used to update the firmware which happened automatically when I logged into mydlink.com for the first time.  The app for my android phone works fantastic and this little camera even has sound!
