There is definitely nothing wrong with the settings, the DCS 920s with very similar browser interfaces have the same settings and work just fine. After six months, I wonder when there is finally a fix for this problem?? I have been a big fan of D-Link but I think I might shop next time somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: Doesn't work well with a external server
Reviews.Author: CoffeeRob
Reviews.Content: We wanted to use this as a wireless weather web cam in our house. After all the reviews I read I though the D-Link web cam could do the job.  First issue was the wireless connectivity. It would connect, but could not get a good signal. So we ran cat-5 ethernet cable to the other side of the house and set up a completely different wireless network. We first tried it 12 feet away and it was 40% percent we were find with that because the ftp working completely fine. It uploaded an image every 30 seconds.  (My mom was really really happy)Then the webcam stopped uploading after about two weeks. So I reset the camera to factory settings and reduced the upload rate to 60 seconds. It also then showed that the wireless was only at 20 percent. So I moved the wireless access point to 5 feet. It was only 5% percent better. So then I tried direct line of sight and 3 feet away and it only gave the signal strength of 35 percent.So I plugged the camera directly into our ethernet cable and that would solve the wireless issue. The FTP would connect but it would not upload the base file name image. It would not upload the base file named image. But it would upload the test image. Sadly the test image would not to the folder I specified but the parent folder of the image I specified.The FTP problems started after almost a month of work properly. I tried a factory reset, I tried every possible setting combination I could. Five years of web design and development and a little problem with a web cam was not going to stop me...I did a few other times and it did work intermittently but it was never reliable beyond half an hour.I phoned the D-Link customer service and that started a 45 minute call of frustration with a fast talking guy with a strong accent who first tried to tell me my poor wireless signal was because my router was only putting out a signal of 35 percent.  But when I told him all other devices were recording 100% strength when they were as close to the router as the camera was. His reply. "I can not comment on your router unless you have a d-link router"Ya that wasn't going to happen, but it's ok we can use the hard wired ethernet cable.The FTP I knew was going to be a hard question and without going into the exhaustive detail that was that frustrating conversation that went around in circles.Q. Do you have the path set.A. YesQ. Can you connect to the FTPA. YesQ. But the test is not going into the right folder?A.  That is correct.Q. You must have set the wrong path.This went around a couple of times. (Like a script or something)Other QuestionsQ. Are you trying to connect to an external networkA. I am trying to connect to a web server. That is what FTP is used for.Q. Maybe try an internal network.A. Why Provide FTP if I can't connect to an external server.Q. I don't know what to tell you sir, but the camera works all the problems you have must be with your network. The camera we have here works perfectly fine.A. Thanks, I will be returning the product.Q. Don't return the camera it works perfectly fine.~~~~~What's worse then a faulty product is the horrible customer service tell me I am doing everything wrong and it works perfectly fine for him.

Reviews.Title: OK image but bandwidth hog
Reviews.Author: Dan Eckhardt
Reviews.Content: This is an OK camera.  Set-up difficulty was 6 on a scale of 10.  Most likely because I have a Mac at home and had to use the beta install tool.  That got the unit working when connected to the router.  I had to call tech support and go through the router-assigned ip address to configure for wireless.  Tech support was OK but if I wasn't an OK tech person, I would have been lost.Image in day mode is decent.  Night mode is grainy.  It would have been better if it was a little crisper.Having said all that, I am still returning the unit because it is a bandwidth hog.  The encoding is JPEG so to get a choppy color image takes between 2000-3000 kbps; the other unit I have encodes at H.264 and I am able to get a comparable image at 512 kbps.  I use internet and internal bandwidth a lot and I plan to have 2-3 cameras.  So this will not work... Too bad b/c the price was good.

Reviews.Title: Great camera.  Difficult setup.
Reviews.Author: Charles G.
Reviews.Content: Setup requires a  tech minded person.  Mac version of software setup works but was written by a bonehead.I have several cameras and remote monitoring works great with airport extreame and iPad 3G AT&T;In time, I developed a problem with a poor wifi signal too.  This was was due to a neighbors router being on the same chanels as mine.  After a lot of frustration I called the manufacture of my wifi router (apple).  After the apple care tech told me that apple does not support non apple products, then  he then "suggested" I manually change the wifi Chanel.  I did and the problem was solved.Thank you apple for fixing a d-link camera.

Reviews.Title: Works well to watch the baby's room/crib
Reviews.Author: MrPuddles
Reviews.Content: This camera works well in the dark and light with latest firmware update.  If you buy this, make sure that you update the firmware and get the latest iPhone app.  Despite comments in other reviews, you can now hear audio through the iPhone app (recent update).  We use this camera in the baby's room to see if he's sleeping without walking in the room.  After using the camera, I intend to buy more to add around the house.Just be aware that when the camera goes into/out of night vision mode - it makes a clicking noise.  This clicking noise could wake a baby that noise sensitive.  Thankfully, our baby could sleep through a riot.

Reviews.Title: Good but not perfect by a long shot
Reviews.Author: California Papa
Reviews.Content: As others say, audio static is horrible but installing them a snap.  However, I ordered two and had problems with both and returned them.  The first one worked for a week and then no longer was accessible via browser or internet.  It was replaced and so far the replacement (a 930 model though) has worked fine for a week.Last night the second 932 became unaccessible on site using a local browser address or through Dlinks web address.  The only way to reconnect the camera to local and internet access was to unplug it and plug it in again.  That is not acceptable because it was for a second home six hours away and the purpose of the camera is to have remote viewing and alarms so therefore this camera was sent back as unreliable.  I have ordered two other cameras of a different model (930s) and hope they prove more reliable than the model 932 cameras i purchase.Although the night viewing capability of the 932 seems to work well if viewing inside the house, you cannot point the camera out a window and use it.  The glass reflects the infrared led light so the image is not acceptable.  If this camera is to be used for outside viewing, the LED has to be turned off and the camera mounted tight to the glass to avoid glare.  Therefore, the model 930 would be a better choice for outside viewing through glass which is my application.  I am very impressed with the free Dlink viewing over the internet and the ability to change settings on the camera remotely as well.  I love viewing my vacation home using my Android tablet or any PC with internet access.  Dlink has an Android application I installed on my tablet and it works great.I will say the cameras are not as wide angled as the older Logitech WiLife cameras I have used for the last 4 years nor is their low light viewing as good.  However, they do not require a computer to be running as the older wilife cameras do and a re way cheaper than the new Logitech Alert cameras which look to be very nice, but too expensive for me from my simple needs.So now I will have to wait and see if the 930 models stay up and running or not and if they do, I will be a happy camper.

Reviews.Title: Great product for this price
Reviews.Author: C. Chantha
Reviews.Content: Easy set up with IPhone iPad compatibility. Video view is great for daytime but nightbview is not good for outdoor. D-cam view software seems complicated for use. Wifi receiving capability is very good. Angle of view is very narrow.

Reviews.Title: Good Unit When its working
Reviews.Author: Jibbie John
Reviews.Content: I bought 2 of these units for my makeshift surveillance camera network. What caught my eye was the web-based feature of viewing your cameras from mydlink.com. Its a lot faster when it comes to recording thanks to the Wireless-N functionality. They work great for daytime surveillance (as long as the sun isn't shining straight on the camera), but becomes useless once darkness rolls in. The DCS-932L is needed for that. I'm not sure well it will work for outdoor use, but its states its good for up to 15ft.I use the D-Link D-ViewCam management software to record daily to a desktop I have connected on the network. It took me a while to fine tune the timing and had occasional issues with the cameras going offline. I plan on reconfiguring the cameras this weekend. We'll see how it works.UPDATE: 9/24/11One camera just started acting up. All I get is bright white and faint images of close-by objects. Talking to DLink Customer Service about this. Having to do multiple resets to see if that will fix it.

Reviews.Title: Easy setup, but poor picture quality when used in-doors
Reviews.Author: Kumar
Reviews.Content: I am updating  the review one month after I went through a replacement and several days and hours of spending time with DLink technical support.  The product has way too many problems and does not work as advertised, in fact, it does not work.  Very flaky.The live video does not work over the internet,but works when viewed over your home network or LAN. It is a good toy to play with.  They say it should work through mydlink site, bit it never did from behind my corporate network.  So, what's the use. My camera is also behind a DLINK's own router at home, so they cannot say that it is their router problem.Kumar

Reviews.Title: Good camera for the price
Reviews.Author: RipeRedRobot
Reviews.Content: I got this camera primarily because it had audio and was low priced. It has been working good for a month now.I use the built-in dynamic DNS client and a port forward on my router to directly go to the camera configuration page and watch the video from there. I used the My-Dlink site a few times but I find the camera page more convenient, plus there were some UPNP issues with it that will only let me watch 60 seconds of video at a time. There are no such issues with the direct web interface.Video and audio work very nicely over the LAN. When accessing remotely, it is a little choppy. You don't notice this much in the video as much as you do in the audio, and is fairly ok.I have it installed in an out of reach location. Initially, I found that it would randomly, but very rarely, decide not to connect to the wireless network even after rebooting it, and I would have to plug in an Ethernet cable to get it back up. This had me worried. But in the month since I installed it in its final place, I haven't had to touch it or reboot it once, and it has been working fine on its own.

Reviews.Title: They gave me someone's returned unit
Reviews.Author: logicguru1
Reviews.Content: I was eager to get the unit,  when I opened it up, I was suspicious that it may have been a returned unit...  Fingerprints on the DVD, cables not tidy, quickstart guide crumbled.  I chose to try anyway... went through full setup on line and first they asked me for a password...  Which means that somebody added a password.  I learned how to reset the password and type my own...  Later in the setup I came across a screen which read  "Unable to add this device to your Dlink account, this device is already registered with another mydlink account, you must delete it from the original account first"  ...which of course I cannot do....  Beware and make sure you get a new unopened unit... I will be contacting Amazon to get a new unit.Update.  increased from 1 star to 2 stars.  Amazon exchanged the unit, and the new one was shrink-wrapped.  This time the setup was pretty quick and the unit is running.  A decent entry level camera for a good price.

Reviews.Title: Great for day or night!
Reviews.Author: Jeremy Livingston
Reviews.Content: I bought this and the DCS-1130.  This one is far better in my opinion.The 1130 said it was "low light" capable, but not really.This camera works great!  I have it setup in the baby room to be able to check on him anytime day or night.  The ability to view it via iPhone/iPad or web makes it super easy!I have recommended it to several friends who also purchased it.

Reviews.Title: Junk
Reviews.Author: Bricks
Reviews.Content: Same experiance as Al.  Leave the camera hardwired and can't be returned!  Purchased to operate on my wireless Verizon FIOS network and will not connect settings.  I can only imagine there is a conflict with Verizon's router (which there must be millions of in use).  Even when using wired there is an extreme feedback "buzz" (high pitched) that makes you disengage your speakers.  Support is non-existent with only the goal of blowing you off.  Sad piece of crap if you have Verizon FIOS.

Reviews.Title: Good product
Reviews.Author: Ronny E. Sanchez Ajun
Reviews.Content: This camera is a very good product, it works exactly as described; however, setting it up for wifi connectivity is a lot easier from the camera configuration settings via IP #, than trying to configure with the wizard. I like this product, it has good reception for a small house under adequate light conditions. Good product.

Reviews.Title: Great and economic cam
Reviews.Author: Catherine "cath"
Reviews.Content: It served my purpose as surveillence cam. I can monitor my place from anywhere. it is the cheapest and best functional cam I could find after doing lot of research.  I would highly recommended.I would consider getting more for other rooms in my house.

Reviews.Title: It works as it says
Reviews.Author: J. Mitchell
Reviews.Content: I just got my dlink camera set up.  I wanted to use it to spy on the pets when I'm working long hours.  It took me about an hour to get it set up, and I don't really know what I'm doing.  I have a MacBook as my only computer and was able to download the Mac installation wizard from the dlink website (it took a few tries to actually down load).  I was able to use that to set up the camera, along with the instructions it downloaded with.  I tried to do it without the instructions the first time and failed, ended up deleting the camera and starting over.  I basically installed it 3 times before getting it right.  It was pretty easy, I had everything I needed supplied, and I was able to get the camera working, wireless and have remote access through the dlink website (its free).The picture is adequate, nothing stellar, but I can see the dogs at the end of the 80' deck.  The microphone works, I can hear the birds chirping.  Not a lot of fancy stuff on this camera, but it serves its purpose.  I think I'm going to get a second one!

Reviews.Title: Works great if it can pick up a wireless signal
Reviews.Author: Kevin W. Gainey
Reviews.Content: I purchased this web camera for watching my front door. Overall everything works great - if the camera can pick up a wireless signal. I have a repeater on the first floor and the camera only connects to the wireless network when it's within 15 feet of the repeater with a direct line of sight. No other wireless devices in my house have this problem. So I may use it elsewhere (wired or wireless) and get something else for the front door. Great video quality related to price and pretty easy to setup.

Reviews.Title: Awesome!!
Reviews.Author: Casey
Reviews.Content: This camera is amazing! It took me less than 15 minutes to set up the camera and all of my accounts with D-Link! I have it set up wirelessly and all it took was pressing two buttons! It connected all by itself. I am definitely buying a few more cameras to put throughout my house! Highly recommend this product!!

Reviews.Title: Decent Camera
Reviews.Author: J. Michael
Reviews.Content: I currently have a LTS Security camera set up but was wanting to buy another one to put in another room.  Set up wasn't that difficult if you know a little about networking.  I just connected it to my router then logged into the router to see what IP address it was given.  After that I logged in using the default user name and password.  The default user name is "admin" and the password just leave blank.  Once logged in you are able to manually set the settings or use a wizard.  The video when there is light available isn't the greatest but it works.  The power cord is very short.  I think they should have made it longer

Reviews.Title: Not quite spy-gear
Reviews.Author: Amanda Richards
Reviews.Content: First of all, the D-Link camera is relatively easy to set up - always the one to play with techie stuff first, my husband had it up and running in a flash (well almost a flash).  Just attach the supplied cable to your computer, run the CD and follow the simple instructions and you're good to go.  According to the instructions, you have two options to set up the camera: wirelessly or wired. Naturally, my husband tried the wireless option first, which didn't work because it claimed (spuriously, we believe) that it couldn't find the network, so he had to resort to the other method, which worked right away. We're using a Linksys wireless router.The camera works quite well indoors where the intensity of the ambient light is generally much lower than outdoors. However, in the brighter outdoor light it is difficult to discern what you're looking at (is it a bird, is it a plane?). The colour is not the best, but then again, it ain't a Nikon 7000. There is some amount of adjustment that can be done online to change the settings, but you'll need to create an online account/register your camera first with D-Link at [...] This is also necessary if you want to view your camera remotely. Strange enough, whenever I try to access the camera online, I get a message telling me that the application needs an earlier version of Java. However, after hitting <Run> for the next three dialogue boxes or so that pop up, it will display the picture. I tried accessing the camera from outside my home network but was unable to do so. Maybe firewall issues?? (Too much effort required to check this). There is also an iPod app that is quite good, minus sound.Night vision was surprisingly good too. In the dark, the images were shades of grey, but in brighter conditions, the colour returned. Four LED lights lit up whenever the night vision was activated (could be an issue if you wanted to place it somewhere discrete).On the down side, the camera has to be plugged into an electrical socket to work, and the cord it came with is very short. This means you have to either place it near an electrical outlet or use an extension cord. This would obviously have limitations on where you can place it. It also has to be connected to your home network whether wired or wireless.While in theory it could be used as a security camera, it has to be powered 24/7, so if you live in a country or area prone to an uneven power supply which could damage sensitive equipment, then you may want to consider that before getting it or you may need to install additional equipment such as line conditioners/UPS to protect your equipment.The sound is not very good. In fact, after a few hours use it started to make a clicking sound in an endless loop.Recommended for limited applications such as keeping an eye on kids (or pets, or pesky guests), or when you're avoiding (hiding from) certain people who come calling at your gate, but not as a dedicated security system.Amanda Richards, June 29, 2011

Reviews.Title: Great bargain....
Reviews.Author: Radbadad "Former Fitness Freak"
Reviews.Content: $70 for this camera is a miracle, but the miracle does have flaws.On the big thumbs up side: D-link gives the user a free web account for "Mydlink" which allows access to the camera from anywhere via a web browser and Internet access.  The user can set up several cameras from various locations.  Just this alone makes the camera a big thumbs up buy.Mydlink "lite" is the application for Iphone, however I can't get it to work outside local network access.  The first thought is firewall blockage, but that's not the problem since the system able to access the local network, but cannot access video from the Internet.  At the same time, access IS allowed via web browser.The software setup wizard is rather lame.  It assumes you use 128 encryption for security.  The user has to open ports for the device to use over the Internet.  The steps are incomplete and require the user to have some network skills.So I spent a few hours researching and installing and the only major disappointment was the inability to use it via my Ipad or Iphone.The sound is poor, but complaining about that in a $70 item is petty.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, difficult installation
Reviews.Author: Erika Mitchell
Reviews.Content: This is a day/night wireless video surveillance camera.  The camera can be used to monitor indoor locations remotely, and it provides sound as well as images.  The camera comes with software for connecting to the mydlink website, as well as an ethernet cable for optional wired connections, mounting hardware, and a power cord (the camera requires power and cannot be run from batteries). The range of the wireless connection depends on your router; with our Netgear G router, we've found the camera can be used as far as 100 feet from the router.  Live video can be monitored from the password protected mydlink website.  The camera also includes software that expert users can set up to use the camera as a motion detector, with the capability of selecting from various zones for motion detection.I was most impressed by image quality picked up by the infrared sensor for nighttime surveillance--images are black and white, but quite clear.  Daylight images are in color, clear enough to use for video surveillance, but certainly not as clear as depicted on the mydlink website.  We found that the sound quality depends on the strength of the wireless signal.  When the wireless signal is good, the sound is quite good, but if there is interference with the signal, the sound can be overshadowed by buzz or hum.  When the camera is in operation, a green LED blinks on the front of the camera, just below the lens.  This blinking light can be turned off; however, we found it useful for monitoring whether the camera was online, since we installed the camera at the very limit of its range from our router.Installation of the camera was a difficult and frustrating battle.  The manufacturer's website claims "mydlink products remove the learning curve that is typically associated with today's high-tech devices because they are truly Plug-and-Play compatible with zero or extremely easy configuration."  I had to go through the installation wizard multiple times to get the software installed and the camera online.  The first 5 times through the wizard, nothing happened.  Eventually, the software linked to the mydlink website.  The next time through the wizard, the camera connected to the website but required new installations of Java and another time through the wizard before it would work.  In addition, to monitoring the camera through the mydlink website, users can set up the camera for advanced functions with the included d-cam software.  While running the d-cam software in Windows XP, my computer blue-screened several times--the first time in years, so I gave up fighting with the software and resigned to using only the mydlink website.  The website claims "mydlink provides you easy and straightforward access to your digital life all from our intuitive, convenient website."  In my experience, the website is far from intuitive or convenient, requiring, for instance, users to log-out before they can access support pages.Overall, the camera itself is a very well-built and handy device, but the installation software is not yet up to par, and the support areas on the manufacturer's website are very poorly thought out.  Expert users who are used to building and trouble shooting networks and connectivity will probably have few problems with installation, but ordinary folks may face a lot of frustration or need to call in help in order to get the camera working.We installed the camera in our turkey brooder in our barn so that we could monitor the young poults, to make sure their heat lamp was on, and their food and water supplies were adequate without leaving the house at night.  We found the sound function of the camera very useful for monitoring the health and comfort of the young poults.  And we were quite impressed with how well the camera stood up to constant pecking by the curious birds.  We wanted to make the video stream from the brooder available to friends as a turkey-cam.  Streaming the video off the mydlink site is apparently possible, but not supported by the manufacturer; thus, can only be done by those who are well versed in network connectivity and coding for streaming video.

Reviews.Title: easy setup on Android g-tablet
Reviews.Author: Dragonspeak "khsdragon"
Reviews.Content: Very simple installation from the CD-ROM and account setup on dlink.com .  Very easy setup on wireless network, pressing the big one inch front button on the ATT uverse two-wire gateway and the reset button on the camera to pair them in one minute.I loaded the dlink lite app from the Android market to the Viewsonic g-tablet and it streams with a 0.1 second delay WiFi to WiFi. Even switching to full screen is fast. WiFi to WiFi on the Android phone is fast but is sluggish on 3g. Viewing on broadband on pc is also fast.The resolution and color is not the greatest possible but is adequate for the cost and value for one room surveillance as a starter or proof of concept that it can be  done.

Reviews.Title: Software Great / Wireless Reception Not So Great
Reviews.Author: Jinxers
Reviews.Content: The surveillance software that comes with this camera is great. It has the ability to record on motion and handles up to 32 separate cameras at once. I have found the software to be rock solid so far with no glitches. One downfall of the software is the fact that there is no help feature or users guide that comes with it so you have to pretty much figure it out on your own. For most users that wont be a huge problem.The Camera itself does have some issues. Picture quality is OK but the real problem is the wireless antennas in these cameras. I had one set up 6 feet away from my router and max signal was 60%. If you are setting up farther than that away from your router forget about the cameras staying connected. To solve the problem of the weak reception from the camera antenna I bought a network range extender and configured it to act as a wireless bridge and hard wired the cameras to it. Now they work like they were intended to but I don't feel I should have had to spend another $65.00 to make them work 15 feet away from my router.Overall the cameras will perform satisfactorily if you can establish a good signal from your router. By the way I was using a Cisco wireless N gigabit router which should be more than sufficient.

Reviews.Title: amazing!
Reviews.Author: Agatha Kristy "•The secret of getting a...
Reviews.Content: If you have an internet connection, you can check in and see what is going on! It works in the dark as well as light. It is in color (when there is enough light, otherwise in a dark room it shows as black and white). It comes with a web link so you can check in and watch what is going on. Great as a Nanny cam or pet cam (I like peeking in on my kids and my pets when I am away from home). You can set it up to record as well.Super easy to use and set up (it took me less than 5 minutes to get connected and I am not a computer expert by any means).

Reviews.Title: good enough for price, however..
Reviews.Author: Patrick D
Reviews.Content: Overall units seem like a good buy. Appear robust for casual use, probably wouldn't want to adjust position too often as somewhat flimsy rotation and lock knob construction. Packaging and setup instructions sufficient to work through setup. Note ONLY PC SOFTWARE comes on provided CD, you will need to download MAC OS version from web. Installation via wireless (N, speed 54mbps or better) router was slow but worked. Second unit setup was easier once I knew what to do. Installation of webcam in final monitoring location was best achieved with looking at live image on laptop, so the camera can be setup to the exact angle needed.The bad - the uplink appears to be fast enough when the laptop is connected directly to the wireless-N router, so the speed of wireless between router and camera is fine to see about 0.5-1 sec update images. Once I left the local network it became a different experience, which makes it almost useless to check remotely from computer (maybe cellphone works but could not try). So you log in to the dlink website and it installs the needed Java real-time software (each time by the way) to provide an image from the camera. Even with 100mbps wired connection the image was very slow to update, and many times could not connect despite multiple attempts. Finally tried to login from a different work computer. Did not have password, so I used to forgot password link. It emailed a default 8 character password. Would not let me login. Tried reset twice more, same problem. So have lost ability to access web-based viewer. Also tried the d-link app on ipad. Just would never connect, timed out.Basically fine if you are on home/local network, although don't expect super fast update. Web-based or app-based access from a remote login site did not work in any useable manner. Give if 1 star for this function, 4 star for basic quality and setup. Don't recommend this if you need to see the webcam from remotely located computer or wifi device as usually can't connect. Disappointing.

Reviews.Title: Problems making it wireless.  My Solution
Reviews.Author: David Y
Reviews.Content: If you want to use it wired it's very easy, and would take about 5min. I wanted it wireless, and I had the hardest time setting it up, i even looked at a YouTube video that didn't help. I pretty much got to the part where it was supposed to reboot, and be good to go but it never rebooted. I use mine to keep watch of my front door since i'm usually at my computer upstairs with a headset on. Doesn't work at night so if you want that option get a different model. For $70 it does what i wanted it for.My wireless solution was to log into my Verizon Fios Router, then click on the DC-930L, click Access Device, and then enable wireless from the D-Link page there. Now it works like a charm, and i love it. Bookmark the page you used to enable your wireless also, its better than using the mydlink site.

Reviews.Title: Not ready for prime time
Reviews.Author: Pete Chen
Reviews.Content: This wireless camera has great features...on paper. In practice, it is just too buggy and not ready for prime time yet. Here are the problems I am experiencing.1. Dlink server not reliable: You have to login to their server to see live video from your camera. Within less than one month since purchase, server was not available for two times.2. Reinstall software every time: Every time I log in, it will reinstall Java Applets. I just don't understand why they cannot use a technology not doing that.3. Camera is offline for no reason: Camera is offline for no reason. I then try it later. It is online again. I tested the internet connection when it happened. It was always on.4. Password is changed for no reason: It happened two times already. It tells me that the camera password has been changes, but it was not. I just had to login at a later time to find out everything is O.K. again.5. Unfriendly software: The live video has zoom-in and zoom-out function. But the zoom-in is digital zoom not optical zoom. That is, it is the same resolution but expands one pixel to four pixels. And the "zoom-in" is always on the center of the video. You cannot zoom in on different places on the video. With these limitations, zoom-in function is pretty much useless to me.6. Mobile apps (iPhone and Android) have no audio. So if you are thinking of using it to replace Lorex baby monitor, then just forget it. By the way, you are missing much anyway. Evewn on Windows PCs, the audio is very noisy. I don't even consider it working.All in all, do not expect much. Do not belive what you see in the ad. Forget about audio, set the expectation low, and wait for the next generation of the cameras. I am going to check another popular one to see if it is better. At least it has better reviews. Foscam FI8918W Wireless/Wired Pan & Tilt IP Camera with 8 Meter Night Vision and 3.6mm Lens (67° Viewing Angle) - White NEWEST MODEL (replaces the FI8908W)

Reviews.Title: Fidgity Installation, Barely Functioning Audio
Reviews.Author: Sheryl Katz
Reviews.Content: The pluses of this camera are that the video view over the web is acceptable for surveillance.  And, once you get it working, it works.The minuses of this camera are that the installation process can be fidgity.  On my home computer, where I first installed it, I had trouble getting the network to recognize the camera.  I have a network hub leading from my main router, and it absolutely had to be plugged into the main router to work.  Once I got the hard wired network connection working, it took several attempts to get the wireless recognized.  I tried using the push button set up for the wireless.  Maybe it matters that I have a Linksys router, but the automated setup wouldn't work.  After I set the camera up at home and tested it I took it to my business.At my business I had more problems with the setup.  For some reason, with the network cable attached the camera kept grabbing the same IP address as the point of sale system.  I had to give the point of sale system a fixed IP and exclude it from the DHCP range.  Then I had to set up the camera and go into the desktop local web interface that is accessed from the camera's ip address.  Once I got there I gave the camera a fixed IP for the LAN.  I still had some trouble getting the wireless to work.  I tried using the push button set up.  Again, maybe because my router is a Linksys, it didn't work.  I was able to manually set up the wireless by using the web interface and typing in the password.Once I got it set up it seems to be working pretty well as a way to see into my business when I'm not there.  However, the sound barely works - it cuts in and out - mostly out.  This camera is really intended for uses like monitoring dogs during the day.  Since I know that all my dogs do is sleep I thought I'd try it at my business.  It would be nicer if the sound works.  DLink needs to fix the installation.

Reviews.Title: Nice item for the price!
Reviews.Author: foxtail_too "Kristi"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for monitoring my home (what do the dogs do when we aren't there?) and I am pleased with the product. It was not difficult to set up and register, and only slightly more difficult to run through our home wireless network.  (Hint: write down the numeric address like the directions say, when it is first assigned.)I have been able to monitor from my work computer without any problems.Monitoring from a cell phone or iPad is somewhat harder. I downloaded mydlink lite on several devices, and monitoring with mobile devices is hit or miss. They seem to disconnect frequently. Hopefully, better apps will solve that problem.

Reviews.Title: Great product, highly recomend!
Reviews.Author: Edward Kissel
Reviews.Content: I use this for checking on my cat when I go on long trips. It was pretty easy to set up (if I had to do it again, I would ignore the WPS option and install initially through a wired connection-they provide a cable). Once you get the device linked to the internet, the only wire needed for a connection is the power cord. I LOVE being able to use the myDlink Lite on my iPhone.

Reviews.Title: Wireless Setup Could Be A Lot Easier
Reviews.Author: thehammer
Reviews.Content: I am a Mac user and, unlike some reviewers, I could setup this camera using my Mac.  However, the software setup procedure was not simple nor straightforward.  Having a good knowledge of LAN is important.  Note, if you don't know what LAN stands for, you might not want to purchase this camera.  If you have a geek friend, keep them nearby.After playing around with the settings, I got it connected and things seem to run pretty well.  I use this as a webcam pointing outside.  On a gray sky, there is a pink to red hue in the center of the picture.  See for yourself at: VisitOregonSouthCoast.com.  Also, the white plastic causes a reflection problem in the window.  I suspect I will have to paint it black.On several mornings, I found that the cam had lost connection with my Verizon supplied wireless router.  When I pulled up the router, I found that there were about 12 connections listed as the cam.  I solved that problem by assigning the camera a fixed IP address.The range is not very good. I can use my laptop two floors away without any problems, but this cam will not connect.  As a result, I have to purchase a second wireless router and run a Cat-5 cable from my DSL router to another floor. I don't know if the external antenna of the earlier model cam would help or not. [D-Link later told me the early model has similar coverage.]I contacted technical support via email with a series of pretty simple questions and they did not respond. [Note: They responded shortly after this review appeared.]SFTP is not supported, which is a huge issue if you need to connect to your website and secure FTP is required.Someday, one of these companies will take an inexpensive still digital camera with a good zoom and modify it so that it can be used as a webcam. That would be perfect.

Reviews.Title: dog's eve view
Reviews.Author: Dan Henrichs "airbrushman"
Reviews.Content: I wanted to be able to see our dog Jasmine in the crate from my iphone.  The camera connects to the wi fi in the house.  My wi fi was not automatic since it was an older model, but the technician at Dlink directed me through the linking process.  I downloaded the free ap from apple that allows me to see the images on my iphone and ipad.  Now when I leave home, I can see the Jasmine in her crate.  The picture is very clear.  You can even zoom in on the crate for a close up.I am very happy with the results and the price was very reasonable in comparison with the higher end models.

Reviews.Title: decent
Reviews.Author: Princess Evelyn Milano
Reviews.Content: This is a decent security camera.  I use it for checking in on my dog when I'm not at home.  The quality is very good during the day, however once the sun goes down you'll need a very bright light to be able to fully see every thing in the room.  I have also noticed that the wireless range isnt that great(I have about a 1600 sq ft house).  My router is on one side of the house.  I initially had the camera in my bedroom(opposite side of the house) because thats where my dog stays a majority of the time, but it kept going in and out repeatedly and not working.  I moved it to my living room which is in the middle of the house and it stays on 24/7 and works fine.  I also love the iPhone app, just wish it had sound.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for watching rooms in your house
Reviews.Author: Bruce
Reviews.Content: After doing quite a bit of research on IP cameras, I settled on this DCS-930L. It was easy to set up using the software and I have had no connectivity issues with the router. I've had the camera for a few months and use the D-ViewCam software from D-Link to set recording schedules for the pets, cleaners, etc. This camera, as a complement to our home security system, is well suited.I do wish the video quality in low light was better, but I suppose it is on par with the price of technology. The power cord is long enough for most applications, but it would have been nice if it were even longer (for flexibility).I will probably buy 1-2 more when I'm ready to add them to a few more sections of the house. I would recommend this product to my friends. (I did not have to deal with D-Link customerless service, so I cannot comment on that aspect... thankfully.)

Reviews.Title: Very user friendly network camera that stays connected.
Reviews.Author: S. Power
Reviews.Content: The automated set-up worked very well with my Linksys E3000 Router.  I was quickly able to set it up to show video anywhere in my house, over the internet, and even on my Android phone, using the Dlink App.It is easy to configure the camera to send e-mails at set times or via motion activation.  It is also easy to have to camera send its data to an FTP site.The range and video quality are both very good.  The automated software and the mydlink website make it all simple to use.  The camera stays connected to the network, and never stops broadcasting.The only task that isn't very easy to set up, is having the video go to a local hard drive.  There isn't a quick and easy way to utilize this feature, though having it save a stream of pictures to a local or remote FTP site is very simple and reliable.Overall, I would recommend this camera.  Everything you would want a wireless camera for is very simple to set up.  I am a complete novice with this setting network devices up, and had no problem.------- Update February 22nd, 2011 ---------I am still very happy with this camera.  Since my initial review, I have continued to have very good experiences with it.  Here are some more observations:- It reconnects to the network within 20 seconds, if you unplug it and move it to a new spot.- Though it works great over Android, they keep updating the software to make it more and more reliable.  The camera always stayed connected to the net, but the phone would sometimes lose the connection.  That is no longer a problem.- Also works on iOS products.- I have played with the Motion Detections settings in conjunction with FTP quite a bit recently.  The camera is working great, and is highly adjustable in this regard, but the FTP service on my Linksys E3000 was giving me problems.  Initially, I thought the camera wasn't working properly, or wasn't adjusting to my settings, but when I switched the FTP to an external site from my router, it is working fine.  Either my E3000 isn't working right, or something with my network settings was causing it to intermittently disconnect.  Either way, it isn't the camera's fault, because it is now working fine, connected to a remote FTP site.  That is better than having it store the images in the house anyway.------ Update July 2011 --------This camera continues to perform very well and gives us a lot of peace of mind.  There is occasional crime in our neighborhood, but an alarm system never seemed worth the expense.  This camera coupled with our off-site FTP storage gives us confidence that we'd at least be able to give the police a photograph of anyone who commits a crime on our property or in our home.

Reviews.Title: Simple & cheap camera solution
Reviews.Author: Pierre Pham
Reviews.Content: DCS-930L was simple to configure. The CD is Windows only however once configured and linked to [...] account you can manage the camera either using Windows Internet Explorer installing D-Link's ActiveX component or on a Mac OS X Safari web browser using Java Applet that is automatically installed. No firewall port or NAT (Network Address Translation) needed for external access (i.e. at work) the cameras from Internet because linking it to the [...] website bypasses the need for any firewall modifications to your local network. To view the camera within your local network you can either use the installed software on the CD or simply use [...] website.DCS-930L is compatible with both Windows & Mac OS.You can also access each camera's configuration using their IP address. Or after logon to [...] click on the linked camera > Camera settings tab. If you're familiar with D-Link's router web interface because the DCS-930L is no different. Within that web interface, options to set camera's date/time, upgrade firmware (none yet available), configure motion detection grid, etc. There's very little modifications needed to the device itself.

Reviews.Title: Pretty good at what it does.
Reviews.Author: Benjamin Michael Chan
Reviews.Content: I bought two of these after reading the review on Engadget, that and having an Amazon package lifted from my front door step.Being that the box and the product description suggests Mac OS support it was surprising not having a way to set it up without using BootCamp, but once in Windows, setup was a breeze. I bought this mainly interested in motion capture, and I am pretty impressed with the setup, you can focus on specific areas of the view to sense motion capture in and a regular threshold based control. FTP and email capabilities let you send pictures based on a schedule or motion capture.I tried the iPhone app too, which worked pretty good, but it is just an iPhone app not a Universal iOS app (iPhone & iPad) so on an iPad you'll have to use the annoying pixel doubling.I would have given this 5 stars, but the issue with no Mac installer and lack of a native iPad app, though not deal breakers for me was a little bit disappointing.For the price, I still think I got a pretty awesome deal.

Reviews.Title: Great Customer Service
Reviews.Author: jane
Reviews.Content: Called customer service for help in setting up recording on DCS 932 L. Agent AR004628 assisted me for a long time in getting my computer set up to record. Would not have been able to do it without his help. Camera is working great now with his help. There is a long wait for customer service. Waited 20 min the first time I called then was cut off. Called another day, waited 38 min only to be told I got in the wrong line. He put me in the correct queue & I waited almost an hr. I got good service but be aware that you may wait a long time. They are open 24/7 & he said late at night was the best time to call. The number for America is 1-877-453-5465. The correct numbers to push are 2-2-5-1. That will get you to the correct agent.This camera will record video continuously or with motion detection. Go to this link to download the software: ftp://ftp.dlink.com/DView/DViewCam_v330_Device_Pack_v142.zip. After you download this go to programs & type in:--DView & click on it--Scroll down to & click dlink bundle--click install pack--click device pack--click setup."Main Console is what you have after it is installed. He got it to work & told me how to do it but I didn't write it down & cannot remember. Will come back with those instructions if I get them. I do remember that the neg button in the lower left corner will minimize it.Another issue is recording or viewing at night through a glass window. You cannot do it because the IR lights on the camera reflect back. I read a suggestion on one of the forums to use a Jelly Lens Wide Angle Fish Eye for Camera Cell Phone. This is the one I bought. Ordered from China for $1. It hasn't come yet so don't know how it will work.Another suggestion was to turn off the Infrared on the camera and use an outdoor light with a movement or heat sensor that will illuminate the outside when motion is detected. Or use an external IR lamp/spotlight.  Gino Infrared IR 12 Led Illuminator Board Plate for CCTV Security CCD Camera; or from places like Maplin/Radio Shack.  Some of the lamps have motion detection to save lamp life, others just work all the time. It was suggested that the cheap IR light board you purchase be affixed directly against the window with the camera several inches away. I have found that the screen must be moved out of the way. Or you could mount the IR board outside. One person said to buy IR Infrared 48 LED illuminator light on eBay or Amazon. They cost $12 on up.Have done a lot of research on this & hope the info helps someone. When I discovered the camera does indeed record I ordered 4 more cameras yesterday as they were on sale for $40 with rebate. Still haven't gotten all the kinks worked out but feel confident it is possible. Using an outside camera might work better but would be much more difficult to install. These cameras can be moved around as needed & go with you if you move.

Reviews.Title: Could not get the unit to communicate with my WiFi.
Reviews.Author: William Ward
Reviews.Content: The best mind in our IT department could not get this unit to communicate with the WiFi system. We finally gave up.

Reviews.Title: 2 uses in one.
Reviews.Author: Brett Gennusa
Reviews.Content: So I hid the camera in the attic to see if there are rats and I was right, this camera is sweet for mere fact of is captioning the Rat Olympics 2013. Thank you d-link

Reviews.Title: JUst what I needed
Reviews.Author: oilman
Reviews.Content: Just what I needed, I have someone with a dog pooping on my front lawn and with this camera I now knows who's dog it is , so I went and took a carp on there front lawn in the dark.

Reviews.Title: Do not buy this camera if you own a Mac
Reviews.Author: David S. Midler "reldim"
Reviews.Content: This camera works great and is easy to setup, but if you use a Mac, you will not be able to view the camera output online,  The easiest way to monitor the camera is by going to mydlink.com.  While the manual says this site works with PCs and Macs, I assue you it does not.  Using a Mac, you will instead get a Java error.  We have tried using 4 different Macs with different operating systems and none will work. Java is installed and up to date. Even our Mac IT guru could not get it to work.  I've emailed D-Link tech support several times and they do not respond.  But, if you search for this issue, you will see hundreds of posts of Mac users with the exact same issue. So, PC, great.  Mac not so much.

Reviews.Title: great tiny camera for the price
Reviews.Author: S. Lee
Reviews.Content: A geek's dream come true. All the non-geeks out there, sorry.Out of the box, it looks like a design rip off of apple.Its tiny and way light. It seems to run warm to the touch.I got it running on my wifi access point and virtualised router. I'm able to access the camera from a remote location and images off my android phone. So far I haven't touched the manual or the included disc yet. I don't plan on touching the useless CDROM. So far the camera has been out of the plastic shrink wrap for a total of 30 minutes.I was able to telnet to it as admin. The embedded OS is busybox. 1.12.1. As user admin, you really can't do any damage to the device.The CPU is: MIPS 24K V4.12. Equivalent to an intel 486 at 100MHz. The linux kernel is 2.6.21.DLink has the entire filesystem on their support website so you can easily modify and repackage to upload to your camera. That way you can root it and modify it.Note that I never registered with dlink's video streaming website. I don't trust anyone else with videos of my home.NEWBIES!! Please don't be discouraged if the camera does not work after 16 hours. Ask someone. Just don't ask tech support. Or you'll get: please tell me the serial number for the 90th time.Not-so-beginners: plug it in your router first and get an address from DHCP. Then just fire up your browser and point to the cameras assigned IP. The IP is depends on what you set your router to serve what IPs.Beginners: tough luck. Please ask nearest geek. Its not easy. Its not your fault. This sort of thing is inherently difficult.EDIT - Feb 15, 2013:Telnet: I guess the new firmware 'fixed' that. You can't telnet into the camera anymore.The built-in HTTPD/web server seems to be dying or refusing connections for some reason. Its still sending images via ftp. But it seems that the camera's built-in web server crashes or more likely the internal flash memory is dying. Or something is wrong. Its been less than a year.

Reviews.Title: Nothing but problems
Reviews.Author: M. Watson
Reviews.Content: I was pretty excited to get this camera. We wanted to be able to see when the kids got home from school for extra piece of mind. It literally took me 4 hours to get this WPS enabled camera to work with my Linksys E4200 router. I've had 5 other routers so I'm pretty comfortable with router setup. I have multiple other items connected to the routers with no issue. Maybe I got a defective camera but WPS would not work. The router works with my other WPS enabled devices btw. When I eventually got the camera manually setup the camera software would not connect to mydlink. The camera would also go into night vision mode in a well lit room. I'll be returning mine today and will start looking for a better product. If anyone has recommendations it would be greatly appreciated.

Reviews.Title: Good video (except in low light), awful audio in mine, and  be wary of the instructions
Reviews.Author: austin_Larry
Reviews.Content: This is a cool gadget and it does work as a surveillance camera over the internet and/or if you have an Iphone with a free Iphone app (no audio on the app). The video is actually good except in low light. It is amazing how basic cameras can produce decent video. However the sound is horrible. I get this buzzing and hissing no matter what room I put it in. And tech support said there was nothing they could do. Keep in mind thought that might be my particular camera or wireless set-up.Which brings me to tech support and setting the camera up to use wirelessly. Do NOT use the instructions. The instructions are going to tell you that you can set up the camera by using the WPS button on your router. At least on mine that wiped out my network settings and made it impossible for computers and phones that had connected before to connect again. My router maker, the highly rated Mediabridge on Amazon, said that every router with a WPS button makes it so that if one device connects that way, they all have to, which is why they don't recommend it. Shame on Dlink for suggesting to use the WPS button when it might mess up people's network settings they use day in day out. That deserves at least a full star off for that alone.So I made multiple calls to tech support. They were always available but not very helpful. But I was able to figure out what to do because I basically figured my only option was to physically connect the camera to my router. You have to manually connect with an Ethernet cable the camera to the back of one of the slots on your router. Then use the Dlink software. This should allow the camera to be found and set up. After you have everything set up and a Mydlink account on the Mydlink page click on camera settings. A new window will open. On that window choose setup and then on the left hand side choose wireless setup. Make sure the SSID has the network name of the network you want to use, if not click site survey and it will look up networks. Then the key to getting it to work not tethered to the router, put in your network password in the Pre-shared key box on the bottom after choosing the correct security you use on your network. Then you should be able to remove the camera from a physical connection to your router and place it where you want. After I did that the camera did take a few minutes to change from red to green, but it does work anywhere now that it has the correct security key.As I mentioned there is an Iphone app. Search for mydlink lite. You have to have already set up your mydlink email and password. Put those in and you can see the video. It does work great but there is no audio, which in my case is fine since the audio scratchiness is unbearable anyway.. It also take surprisingly good pictures and saves them to your camera roll. Tech support kept saying you download the app from our website. And I kept saying that doesn't sound right are you sure the app isn't in the Apple app store? And of course it was in the app store. So it is what it is with their tech support, not impressive. Even with the bad manual and bad tech support I still would have given 4 stars if the audio had been ok. But my audio is unusable. However that might be some quirk with my network connection. But every other job I am asking my router to handle it is doing a superb job. So I either got a lemon audio wise or the audio is a problem. But for a basic surveillance camera, once it is set up it works pretty well. And the Iphone app is a nice fun thing.

Reviews.Title: Not worth the Headache
Reviews.Author: 2012EndGame
Reviews.Content: Here is my goal:My mother is an older retiree on a fixed income who has experienced fainting episodes lately, and occasionally falls; she also has helpers who we suspect of abuse.  I was looking for an IP camera that I can setup and record and watch what is happening in her house remotely.The Issue:My mother has no high speed Internet no cable, no DSL, only a simple phone line.My Solution:1. Purchase a Verizon, Sprint, Tmobile 3G/4G Hotspot and use that as Internet.2. Purchase an IP Camera like Belkin, Dlink, Dropcam or some other Cloud Based Camera and connect it to the hotpsot for Internet Access.Issues:I would like to share some of the issues I encounter in my project that cost me $$$, 600 Miles round trip and a whole weekend trying to get it to work.You can take this review for what its worth or toss it.  However if I can save you some time, money, and frustration then my review will have served its purpose.Timeline:Thursday 01/24/13 Bought a Tmobile Hotspot since my mother lives in a 4G Coverage area and Tmobile has no Overage over data usage, Unlike Verizon, and AT&T.;Friday 01/25/13 Bought the DLINK Cloud Cam and Belkin Cloud Cam from Frys Electronics, tested both cameras on my home network everything worked fine.Saturday 01/26/13 Made the 3 hour trek to install.  Setup the Cameras to connect via WIFI to the TMobile Hotspot.  Could not view cameras over the network.Issue 1: Cellular Carriers require Static IP Addresses because the Cellular Broadband Network sits behind a NAT firewall, which blocks all users from displaying a public IP address.  Tmobile, Verizon Wireless and AT&T;, US Cellular want $500 for a static IP Address.  Sprint only $3 a month.Issue 2:  The Cameras are constantly streaming to the Internet.  Streaming Data will amount to 60-80 GB a month for just the cameras streaming to the Internet.Saturday 01/26/13 Pack up my equipment and head home for another solution.EUREKA I struck Gold!Sunday 01/27/13 after doing some google searching I found a great little Camera called CloudCam from 3gstore.com, I placed the order.The camera boast that you can be up and running in minutes and can be viewed anywhere remotely.  I order the CloudCam Indoor Wireless IP Camera WHITE Camera.Thursday 01/29/13 I received the CloudCam IP Camera via Fedex from 3gstore.com.  It included a Camera, Ethernet Cable, mounting brackets, CD, and Wireless db gain antenna.  I Plug it into my computer and within 2 Minutes I was able to configure it to my Wireless Network, Once I tested the camera on my home Network and made sure it operated fine.I switched it over to the TMOBILE Hotspot.  What happen next was short of a Miracle.  I was able to view a live feed from the camera to my Android Phone most importantly over a cellular Network with the Camera connected to the TMOBILE wireless Network without a STATIC IP ADDRESS.I wanted to do a more serious test so I placed the Camera in my car and threw the Hotspot into the glove Compartment and had my wife drive around town.  From My android phone I could see her drive around the city LIVE.  I was ecstatic that it worked so well.  A few other perks I like about the Camera is that it has Micro SD Card slot to record to a MicroSD or you can configure it to record to a NAS Storage Device.  It has a built in Microphone, and records at night.1/30/13 Noticed the Camera was sluggish on TMobiles Network, I ended up going to Verizon Wireless Store and picked up a 3GB PrePaid USB Plan for $60.00 and inserted the sim card into a (Pantech UML290) Placed it into a CradlePoint Router CTR35 and set a Ping Target to keep the connection always On.  Downloads and Uploads were sufficient over the LTE Network1/31/13 I pack up the gear and head to my mother's house.  I installed the Gear and right away I opened the CloudCam Android App and they have an Iphone App too and I was able to view instant Live Feed.Peace of Mind:You cant put a price on Peace of Mind.  I now have a camera that streams live when I request it, but constantly records onto a Micro SD Drive so in case I need to review the backup footage.Being able to check up on my mom to make sure she is ok. Priceless! See link below:[...]

Reviews.Title: Unusable
Reviews.Author: Paul
Reviews.Content: I bought one of these at Fry's. Try as I might, I couldn't get the "cloud" based configuration software to work. Every time I tried to configure the motion sensing, a "Loding" (yes, that's what it said) graphic would come up, followed by the old IE "page cannot be found". There is nothing wrong with my connection, browser, or machine. I tried this several times. If manufacturers are going to be lemmings and jump on the "cloud" bandwagon by placing all the basic software functionality there, they should make sure it's rock solid. This kind of junk make this camera unusable.

Reviews.Title: Nice features but buggy
Reviews.Author: ath "ath"
Reviews.Content: I like all of the features on this camera like the motion detection and the sd card capability but it seems like the firmware running this camera is buggy.  At first everything installed just fine.  The my dlink allowed me to view the camera from remote places.When I tried to use sd recording, I started having problems.  When I first put the sd card in, it wasn't recognized by the camera.  After restarting a couple times, the camera found the sd card and let me format it, but wouldn't record to it.  I reset the camera to factory defaults and re-ran the original setup and then it started recording to the sd card.  I set the camera up to record with motion detection.  After about two weeks, I noticed that it would only record about 5 seconds of video and then show a frozen frame for the remainder of the video clip.  So for a 20 second video clip only 5 seconds was motion video with the remainder of the time the frozen image of the 5 second mark.  I have now reset everything back to factory defaults again to see if this will fix the problem.I wouldn't recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Frustration within minutes...
Reviews.Author: John S. Dean "John"
Reviews.Content: I've been in IT since the early 80's.  I build networks, so wireless isn't anything intimidating for me.  I thought, based on some reviews here, that I'd have this up and running quickly and easily.  And I was wrong.  VERY wrong.First I tried to do it wirelessly, since that's what I bought the wireless version for.  Another reviewer had issues with an Apple Airport Extreme, but I thought I'd try it anyway.  And no matter how I set it, what encryption or lack thereof, what mode (802.11 a, b, g, n), the setup program just gave the red error that it could not configure the network.  Alright, someone else had problems with Apple, so I pulled out some of my older units I've had in the past.  Started with a simple Linksys 802.11g unit.  Same problem.  Pulled out a 3com wireless router, 802.11g, same thing.  Set for 802.11b, same thing.  Pulled out a Netgear 802.11 b/g unit.  Same thing.  No matter what I tried, it failed setup with their automated process.  Found a different program on the CD that just lets you get at the hardware without setting up the online stuff, so tried that - same thing.  Tried setting things static as opposed to DHCP, same fail.  So I left it wired, and got it on the network that way.  Then I hit the built in admin webpage on the unit itself, set up the wireless on all the units one at a time again, same thing.  So I figured I'll at least see how it works wired.I have a static IP, and opened the ports I set the unit on through the firewall.  From the program or the built in webpage, I could see the output fine, but as others have said the audio was horrible.  Loud hissing even when things were dead silent and there was no noise it was picking up.  Video, while not great quality, at least impressed me with how high the viewing framerate was.  This is my third unit I'm trying, after having problems with the Logitech unit, and the dropcam.  The others weren't as smooth with the video display, just higher quality.  And the night viewing worked pretty well also for the testing I did in my house at night, all lights off.  "Lit up" a surprising amount.  So I could watch it locally, time to set it up for the mydlink website and my iPhone.Got the account created fine, but even though the unit was working locally on my network, and even though I could access it directly via IP from outside my network, it took me almost an hour to beat it into submission to join itself to the dlink webservers.  But through their servers, it NEVER showed anything but a black box.  I could still access the video from outside the network directly with a web browser (and was nice that it supports both ActiveX and Java, so worked on both my macs and my PC's) but it never worked through their system.Then I tried the iPhone app.  Again, fail.  Got that set up to use my Dlink account, logged in fine, listed my camera fine, but nothing ever got through video-wise.  Just timed out.Tried to contact Dlink support, no replies.  Even posted on their beta support forums, nothing even from other users in the peer support forums.So it was boxed up and returned.  All told, about 10 hours I spent trying to get this to operate, and while I could get it to operate in a limited, wired, web browser only access mode, nothing else ever functioned right.

Reviews.Title: Setup doesn't work with Linksys Routers
Reviews.Author: sayWhat
Reviews.Content: We have a Linksys Wireless G Broadband router.  I was running the installation disc on a Windows Vista laptop.  The installation went fine until it got to the point of saving the settings of the wireless network.  Repeatedly came back saying the this step failed, try again.  I tried this step repeatedly and it failed every time.  The only suggestion the documentation made was to make sure my PC was wired into the router (as opposed to wirelessly), which it was.  In fact, I disabled every wireless device we had in our house so that all I had was the router, the camera connected to the router with an ethernet cable, and my Windows laptop connected to the router also through an ethernet cable.  Not much left to do.  So I called tech support.  They took some information.  When I mentioned the Linksys router, the operator let out a small, barely detectable moan, which I took to be related to a competitor part.  I now think it's because they have been getting a lot of calls about their cameras not working with these routers.  Anyway, they told me a level 2 service technician would call me back within the hour.  That was over 2 hours ago.  So it's going back.

Reviews.Title: Not really worth it
Reviews.Author: Offdahookluke
Reviews.Content: It works sometimes..& 4get da motion activated. It can't stay connected even plugged directly into router & 4get sound. Buy sumthin betta. Trust me!

Reviews.Title: Good low-priced, low featured camera.
Reviews.Author: Michael D Opel
Reviews.Content: Good basic webcam. Very good for price. Easy to install and easy to access remotely thru MyDlink. Res is kind of low and doesn't have a very wide angle.  Also, lack of IR limits its use for security functions

Reviews.Title: Excellent!
Reviews.Author: Diego Armando Castro
Reviews.Content: The cam is a excellent product, I am happy because I use the cam for security and watch my home. 100% recommended.

Reviews.Title: Lots of pain for much inconvenience
Reviews.Author: Danrogy
Reviews.Content: How do I hate this product? Let me count the ways:D-Link claims this product has 24/7 tech support, only they have like one person answering the phone. I use computers every day & am a pretty smart guy. Why then was the tech support lady so nasty and condescending? I had to wait over 40 minutes in the queue (even though the timer said it'd only be 25), then had to deal with this nasty woman for another 45 minutes speaking to me as if I was a half-wit. For all that attitude, she still couldn't help me set up the camera using Wi-Fi. OK fine, so maybe that's not her problem, even though I have a new router from a major company.So I'd like to set up some of the other aspects of the camera, including watching the camera live remotely. Only the camera doesn't support Java 7. Java 7 is already a year old & ships on Macs. Nowhere does it say this in the packaging, so now you're forced to deal with the tech support nightmare only to be told "this is a known problem. Contact Apple & figure it out yourself"So since I can't use any up-to-date Apple products to adjust or watch the camera, I decided to use the Windows computer at work. What's that? You want it to capture full-color in the daytime and infra-red at night? Ya-no. It's infra-red all of the time or it's color all of the time. Sure there's an automatic button to make it change during different lighting situations, but using it makes the camera infra-red 100% of the time.OK, so now I'd like to set up the motion detection, especially because it's impossible to record constantly. It's such a nice tool! How convenient that it'll send you an email of six frames on either side of the motion detection. Too bad it doesn't work. You can pick a number of regions on the image to get motion (I believe nine) and you can also set up its sensitivity. Cool! So I try it at 100% with half the regions covered. Every air pressure change that shakes my front door sends me another email. I think I deleted a few hundred over the weekend. So I (having to wait until I'm at my work computer) change the settings to 50% sensitivity. Still hundreds of emails. Then I set it to 20%. OK now I'm down to 40 emails per day (of my non-moving front door). The last straw with this hopeless piece of trash was when I have only one region selected at 1% sensitivity. I'M STILL GETTING DOZENS OF EMAlL PER DAY!!! Yes, of my non-moving front door.A quick recap:Practically nonexistent customer serviceReprehensible, condescending tech support that'll take hours of your timeWon't work on a MacWon't work wirelessly with a new Netgear routerMotion detection sucks & will email you hundreds of worthless emails.I'm gonna go shop for a non-suck option

Reviews.Title: Very Easy to Use
Reviews.Author: R. Adams "Ms. Adams"
Reviews.Content: After doing a lot of research and comparisons, I decided to try out the D-Link DCS-932L.  I bought this not so much for home security, but more for checking up on the pets while I'm gone and watching to see which one is causing the most trouble when I'm not around.  I wanted a camera that had pan/tilt capabilities, but they were either too expensive or too complicated to set up.  So I bought this and have it set up on my mantle in the living room which gives the widest viewing angle of the living room.  I've already read previous reviews as well as their website so I was aware that it would be easy to set up, but was still surprised by the simplicity of it.  It was really just a matter of taking it out of the box, plugging it in, and going to their website.  I also downloaded their free app from the Android Marketplace for both my tablet and phone and the app is very clean and simple to use.  After logging in, it shows you a list of all the cameras you have set up (for now I just have the one in my living room, but I'll probably get a couple more for the kitchen and master bedroom) and after selecting which camera you want to view, it pops up on the screen rather quickly, even when on 3g.  I'm able to easily check on my home when I'm at work, at the park, or anywhere else I can get a cell signal.  I did have some difficulty viewing it on my default browser (Chrome), but that might have to do with the browser still being relatively new.  The picture quality isn't the best, but it's clear enough that I'm still able to tell what's going on.  The colors are pretty washed out, almost completely black and white really, but again this isn't too much of a problem for me.  Also, just like previous reviewers have pointed out, this camera produces a lot of static noise.  Even when everything was turned off in the living room with all the windows closed, there was still a lot of static noise.  I'm not sure how this would affect conversations or low level noises you wanted to listen in on.  The night vision is great; I can clearly see the living room even when it's pitch black.Even with the shortcomings, I think this is a great camera.  The price point is excellent, it's extremely easy to set up, and the night vision is fantastic.  If you can deal with a stationary camera that shows the picture in black and white and static noise, you won't be disappointed.  It works for what I need it to work for and I intend to buy at least two more.

Reviews.Title: Frustrating start but got it going
Reviews.Author: O. Awad
Reviews.Content: I was almost about to return this product to Amazon until I decided to give the WPS with my TimeCapsule a shot!If you are a Mac user you need to setup this product on a Windows machine I used bootcamp. You need to use the enclosed CD wizard which is slow and frustrating (you'd think in 2010 setting up an N network device would be straight forward!). I ran the wizard with the Camera attached to my TimeCapsule router which is really an Airport extreme with built in hard disk multiple times. It found the Camera and allowed me to assign a password to it. It wouldn't identify the internet access (DHCP) in my case. And the most frustrating point was once it scans for the network and I put my password for WPA security it wouldn't go through. I kept getting an error message with an advice to use an Ethernet connected computer to complete the process. I had to move my router to another room to try to do that and still with the same result. I actually gave up and started repackaging to return to Amazon. But I googled WPS connection to see if I can try it. Luckily I could. WPS is a way for you to connect a wireless device to a secured router without entering a password. Most of the time it gives you one to two minutes to press a WPS button on both the device and the router and they connect to each other without having to enter any information. Airport extreme and from my understanding a lot of other routers while not having a physical button to push do have the capability for WPS from the administrative software for the device (check your router manual or google it) . On the Airport extreme you launch the Airport Utility, select your router, Go to manual setup and from the top menu choose base station and then select add wireless client and Click the WPS  on the camera and then the corresponding software button on Airport Utility and just like magic they connect. I wish I knew this before I wasted more than an hour trying to setup a connection with the Ethernet Cable.Once setup you go on with the CD wizard you setup a mydlink.com account and it works. Once you do that you don't need the CD (or windows for that matter) I setup 2 iphones to check on the Pets bedroom which is why we got the camera.The quality is not that impressive but I got it for surveillance and for that it does what it should.The bottom line it does what it says. The setup can be much easier (something for D-link to work on) and most of all if you can use WPS connection and avoid Ethernet cable configuration.

Reviews.Title: Fun and functional cameras!
Reviews.Author: S. Pigford
Reviews.Content: We use three of these handy little things to monitor a mountain cabin. Two are aimed out windows front and back, and the third is set to view an internal thermometer. With the motion-detection email feature, we have a number of photos capturing animals, including a moose. Fun! The inside camera sends me several overnight pictures that have reassured me about the inside temperature's staying OK after some heater issues. We can of course look at any time to see the current outside (and inside) weather conditions.A recent Dlink website update and new camera firmware (easy to install), have greatly enhanced the viewing with larger, even full-screen views and easier access to functions such as motion detection areas and sensitivity.We've had no technical problems, though some settings were hard to do, but all this seems recently fixed with the new website and firmware. Also, smartphone viewing is possible, even with a Windows (Nokia) app!Great, inexpensive solution to our distant monitoring needs.

Reviews.Title: D-Link DCS-930L Camera
Reviews.Author: lovestotravel
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because of the fairly low price and the fact that i didn't need nighttime viewing. I have some Samsung Smartcams that have IR. The D-Link serves my purpose, but the image is not as sharp as the image from the Samsungs. It was fairly easy to set up.

Reviews.Title: Decent camera but took way too long to install
Reviews.Author: Brian
Reviews.Content: Decent camera but took way too long to install - router would see them when plugged in with Ethernet cable but not wireless. Finally 3 hours later and a step solution posted by someone on the internet I was successful. Was not a straight forward WPS plug and play for a wireless device.

Reviews.Title: worried
Reviews.Author: Melisa
Reviews.Content: I purchased 3 of this camera but I am worried because how can you put the camera outside where it needs to be plug in the router. It won't work if it does not plug in the router. Hhmm a bit confused here.

Reviews.Title: Solid, inexpensive and performs as advertised
Reviews.Author: Tony Mason
Reviews.Content: This is my fourth purchase of the same type device, all four work well. Used for home monitoring from the web and smartphones. Easily determine if home alarms are false or positive. Went on vacation and noticed that we'd left a candle burning, called the neighbor to take care of it. Setup is really easy, alerts on motion are easy to set up. Picture isn't great, but sufficient for the intended purpose. Very good product for the money that you spend.

Reviews.Title: Easy to set up and works great
Reviews.Author: Sheila Clover
Reviews.Content: I put off setting it up because I thought I'd have to read a manual to get it all going. That was not the case. It was pretty easy to get it set up and to get the app on my iphone.  The only problem I have with it is now I'm addicted to spying on my dogs!! LOL  I do a lot of animal rescue and fostering and now I can keep an eye on my own dogs and the new foster dogs all day long and from anywhere! This has been such a successful purchase I plan on getting another one!

Reviews.Title: works beautiful for a baby monitor!
Reviews.Author: Diane
